text: Draft at Armsby Abbey. Pours black with an inch of khaki foam. Leaves a shitload of lacing in the glass. Massive roasted chocolate malt notes on the nose. Lots of chocolate on the tongue. Very thick and luxiourius with a bit of hoppiness on the finish. Just a gorgeous gorgeous beer.
Black pour, small brown head. Amazing aroma of coffee, roast, dark chocolate, and cocoa. Taste follows, very roasty.

Pours a dark black color with a nice mocha head. Nose of vanilla, chocolate malts, roasted coffee, woodyness, dark fruits, caramel malts. Taste is incredibly smooth, so creamy and thick. You get a lingering toastiness from the roasted malts. Full body. Finish is a bit dry. Extremely well made.

4 oz pour on draft at ChurchKey during the Hill Farmstead tap takeover on 4/1/2017. Not an April Fools Joke. Black with tan head. Aromas of roasty notes, caramel, dark chocolate. Tastes of caramel, dark chocolate, roasty notes, coffee. Medium body with a dry finish.
Lots of roast. And some coffee. Light caramel. Creamy consistency. Black pour with good head and lacing. Bitter finish. Better than shirly Mae like Shirly Temple. Nice. Tap at Churchkey.

Shared at gregwilsonstl house. It poured a black color with a dark brown head. The aroma was of dark roast, bitter chocolate, caramel, malts, light smokiness and dark fruits. The taste was similar to the aroma with more dark chocolate, roast, caramel, tobacco, licorice, light smokiness, wood and dark sweet fruits. Tasty.

This could be the best porter Ive ever had. The look is spot on, dark with a huge mocha head. The smell was outstanding, tons of chocolate, coffee, and hints of tobacco. The flavor follows suit as you get a bitter dark chocolate mixed with coffee and nice spicy finish. The feel is on the creamier side with a good amount of carbonation.

Hunted by Sergey; bottled 4.6.16Black color, medium brownish head. Aroma of roasted malt and dark bread, light wet cardboard, pungent. One of the smoothest beers, relatively dry; roasted malt, dark chocolate, cardboard, touch of liquorice.Excellent.

Tasting at Alexs. 500ml, bottled on 06-Apr-2016 (thx, Alex M.!). Pours an almost black with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, dark fruits, aome chocolate notes. Taste is huge roasted malt, black chocolate notes, very dry and even some boozy notes. Very good.
Aromat to tytoń, paloność, dym, lekki fenol. Smak lekko gorzki i słodki, kakao, tytoń. Solidna rzecz.
Wyrazista, mega ciekawa paloność, sporo tytoniu, długa, kawowa goryczka, wyraźny aromat dymu. Bardzo klasyczne i bardzo smaczne. Mógłbym pić codziennie.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2017 Panel #1 Rami Rami is drinking an Everett by Hill Farmstead Brewery at Chmielarnia MarszałkowskaKawa, siano, tyton, palonosc, mooze dym... Dlugie posmaki wytrawne, popiolowe. Latwo pijalne, ale nie urywa nicOcena potraktowana skryptem do przeliczania ocen (uzgodnienie UT/RB).
24 oct 2016, bottle. Black. Nose is outstanding! Meaty, some char. Med body and mildly fizzy. Meaty, earthy, tobacco, sweet and tobacco. Wow!

Pours pitch black with a fluffy, bubbly, mocha colored head.

Smells of melted chocolate, toasted walnuts, rock sugar and unsweetened marzipan. The nose comes very well together, balanced by a mellow earth note, including a whiff of dough and flowers, adding to the prominent chocolate.

Has an utmost soft mouthfeel, creamy with a medium, malt relying body, featuring a lively carbonation burst, tickling the tongue during the finish.

Tastes of milk chocolate, bitter cocoa nibs, which add to the complexity of the silk chocolate, and toasted hazelnuts. Turns a tad dryer during the mid palate with even more cocoa nibs, a whiff of licorice and lots of soothing cream. Finishes with rock sugar, fudge and bitter chocolate, clean and soft.

Very well built Porter, pleasantly complex without loosing its focus at any point. Intense during the mid palate, while finishing surprisingly soft and calm.
At Hopishop 2016. Aroma of coffee, roasted malt and some choco. Taste has coffee, caramel, licorice and malt. Not bad, but very middle of the road.

At Hopishop. The best porter in the world according to this site - for what its worth. Lightly lacing, tan, moussy head quickly dissipating in the middle; very dark mahogany brown colour, blackish but still fully translucent. Aroma of beef stock cube and even gravy, walnut, home made caramel, dry liquorish candy, dried porcini, bitter chocolate, vague glue-like solvent effect but nothing disturbing. Sweet onset, hints of candied figs and dates, sourish undercurrent, beef stock-like umami accent from the nose returning immediately after the sweetness, softish carbo perfectly fit for the style, smooth oily mouthfeel, caramelly malt core with bitter chocolatey and mildly toasted ending, pleasant spicy hop notes blending in very well, lingering with the toasted malt bitterness, a tad grapefruity in the end, with a mild suggestion of warming alcohol. Very accomplished, rounded, easily drinkable porter, perhaps a bit too much tilted to the umami side for this style but I can see how this quality level in combination with limited production and even more limited distribution can create a hype.
Pours dark with thick chocolate colored head. Incredible beer. Roasted malt, chocolate. Very smooth mouthfeel. Thanks to Frank for trading this to me. I absolutely will seek out more.

(On tap @ Warpigs HF Day, Copenhagen, May 12 2016) Pours pitch black with a massive medium tan head and lace carpet. Aroma of coffee, light smoky notes, grain, dark malt, unsweetened chocolate. Palate is loaded with lightly burnt malts, cacao, ground coffee, toffee, light vanilla, pine boughs, mineral, moderately bitter hoppy finish with supporting roast. Mega balance. Medium full with below average carb. This is a pitch perfect normal porter that I could drink on any given day, the water chemistry seems to help hone quite typical elements into something much better than typical.

Donkerzwart bier met fijne witte schuimkraag. Heel mooi licht rokerig aroma. Koffie, rook, chocolade, beetje tabak, rozijntjes. Maar als je een slok neemt vind ik dat het bier gelijk beetje verwatert in de mond. Beetje vlak. Kan ook liggen aan de flinke stouts die ik hiervoor had gedronken. Al bij al goeie porter maar geen wauw effect.

500ml bottle purchased on site at Hill Farmstead. Pours a thick oily black with an everlasting, thick brown foamy head. Aroma has some roastiness with a hint of cherry and chocolate. Taste roasty, coffee, chocolatey. Very Smooth mouthfeel and leaves a wonderful aftertaste of dark chocolate cocoa. Top notch Porter, best around.

On tap at brewery. Nitro. Pours a nearly black dark brown with a large light brown head. Roasty aroma of coffee with some wood. Tastes of roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate. Lightly bitter coffee finish. Full body. Rich, creamy, and a little bit oily mouthfeel.
Bottle, shared at RBAG by me. Very dark brown, light brown head.nmilk chocolate, brown bread, lightly nutty, dry finish. Balanced and rich.

text: On tap at Warpigs, Copenhagen. Hill Farmstead tap takeover. Pours black with light brownish head. Roasted malts, chocolate, cocoa, some coffee notes, hops with some citrus. Sweet with bitter finish. Medium to full bodied. Quite smooth and easy drinkable.

Bottle 0,5 at Slacker. Pours black with large beige head, excellent lacing. Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate, dried fruits, some wood. Very mild and pleasant. Taste is coffee, cocoa, dried fruit, licorice, roasted malts. Once again very mild and pleasant. Full body, oily texture and soft carbonation.

Bottle with Bob. Dark brown close to black with a large diminishing light brown head. Nose has roasted malt, chalk, dark bitter chocolate, vanilla, twigs. Soft and filling mouthfeel, mild acidity. Wood, vanilla, roasted malt, chocolate cake, chalk, minerals, earthy. Faint citrus and flowers. Soft and gentle.
Dark black. Dry. Mocha head. Shared with John (porch beer!) Cocoa nibs. Somewhat bitter. Burnt flavor.

The beer pours dark brown with a dense tan head. The aroma had smooth roast, licorice, chocolate, coffee and a bit of woodiness. It has a pretty full body with soft carbonation. The taste has deep roast, molasses, cocoa and woody hops. The finish is a little on the char side. quite good.

Hill Farmestad tap takeover at Warpigs may 12th 2016. Black body with a light brown head. Aroma is roasty with chocolate and toffee. Taste is sweet, coffee, cocoa, malty. Good balanced, finish brings a mild hoppiness. Quite nice!

Black pour with a perfect khaki to tan head and sticky lacing .... Aroma of cocoa, chocolate, tobacco, roasted malts, coffee and caramel malts ...... Taste is of cocoa, roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and caramel malts .... Mouthfeel is slick, oily and the body is soft and creamy .... Finish is roasted, bitter and has lingering cocoa and coffee ... Excellent Porter

Bottle thanks to Bytemesis! Poured dark chocolate brown with a tan head and angel food lacing. Aromas of roasted caramel and chocolate malt, toast, molasses, and nuts. Flavor is mild cocoa bitter. Tasty!!
Tap Black colour with small head.Aroma of english licorice and roasted coffee,caramel and malt,smooth taste and hint of dried fruits and hops,sweet and light by styl of a Porter.

Bottle shared at Johnnys Off License, Rome. Pretty, darkest brown with soapy brown head. Balanced sweet roast aroma. Gentle, rich refined, sweet espresso. Mild bitter and a touch of alcohol. Good acidic note to balance it all. Really nice. 8 4 8 4 17

Bottle: Thanks MacBoost: Served in a Chouffe:
Creamy light brown head. Black body.
Aromas of roast, chalk, carbo gass, dark chocolate, light coffee, coal, pencil grind, tobacco, hint of cardboard...
Flavour is roasty, dark chocolate, herbal roast, bitter, light carbo gass, light coffee, malt roast...
Aftertaste is bitter, light dry, roast, tobacco, coal, dark chocolate...
Low carbo, light watery light creamy mouthfeel, more than medium bodied.

text:
Draught @ Hill Farmstead Day - Warpigs Brewpub, København
Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and hint of licorice. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter with a long chocolate, coffee and licorice finish. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2016 Tap at The Farmhouse in Burlington with the ECBT crew. Deep black in color with a very attractive tan head. Aroma is big on coffee, chocolate malts, and a toasted nuttiness. Taste has a little smoky quality but predominantly chocolate, espresso, vanilla, and roasted notes. Smooth, silky mouthfeel with plenty of depth. Really enjoyable finish with lingering coffee aftertaste. One of the better porters I?ve had and not just because of the brewery name. Delicious.

Dark brown to almost black in color... Light tan head... Aroma of dark roasted malts, chocolate... Mouthfeel is silky, lots of dark chocolate, roasted malts, anise... Cocoa nib bitterness on palate, solid but I think the ratings are a little inflated cuz it's HF

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Black color with mocha head. Aroma has coffee, chocolate, caramel and sweet malts. taste follows with sweet coffee and roasted malts. Finishes with coffee bitterness. Body is medium with a nice, smooth mouthfeel. Really good porter but I had higher expectations.

On tap at WarPigs Brewpub, Hill Farmstead Day. Deep rosewood coloured body. A bubbly ring to the rim of the surface. Spotty lacing. Nicely roasted dark malty aroma. Similar flavours of dark malts, including moments of chocolate and coffee. Smoothly roasted aftertaste. Well bodied. Good drinking in the sun at the brewpub (shared with KimJohansen, Copenhagen 12.05.2016).

on tap,poured into a tulip glass..dark brown with a medium tan head..aroma 
of chocolate,coffee,roasted nuts,espresso..tastes of all the previous..medium
bodied..very good.

Tap @ Warpigs. very dark brown with small beige head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, espresso and a little liquorice. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, liquorice, hop, medium bitter, medium sweet and a little salt liquorice.
On tap at Warpigs, pre-CBC. Pitch black with an espresso head. Chocolate, cocoa roastness, espresso. Medium body with low carbonation and a bitter-sweet aftertaste.

Draught @ Warpigs, Copenhagen. Pours black with a tan head, lacings. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, expresso, dark chocolate, light nuts. Flavor is malts, coffee, expresso, nuts. Medium body, average carbonation. 120516

En fût au Three Penny Taproom de Montpellier, VT. La couleur est noire, très opaque, avec un bon collet de mousse. Le nez et le goût sont trèes près, avec notamment le malt grillé, un peu de torréfaction, café fin, chocolat, et lait. Wow! me laisse littéralement sans mots. La profondeur de ce porter est littéralement incroyable. Larrière-goût de chocolat est incroyable, et même pour moi qui nest pas très friand du goût de café, cette bière est extraordinaire. Re-wow.
On tap at Warpigs in Copenhagen. Smell of chocolate and caramel. Similar taste with dark malts and roasted aromas. Very tasty. Nice roasted and chocolaty malt base.

Tap at warpigs. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, caramel, chocolate. Hoppy notes of citrus. The flavours starts sweet but finish bitter with long roasted duration. The body is full and the texture is creamy. Great...
Tap at Warpigs, Copenhagen. Colour is dark brown with small brownish head. Aromas and flavors: Chocolate, coffee and roasted malts. Nice soft chocolate porter.
Black, light tan head. Burnt malt, coffee, licorice. Thick mouthfeel. Dry coffee flavour with roast and licorice. Long, bitter licorice finish. Good.
Tap warpigs. Pour pitch black with a brown head. Aroma of roast, choko, coffee, malty. Taste is roast creamy, rather sweet, light hops, chokolade. Very drinkable

Tap @ Warpigs, tap take over. Black with a big and lasting brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, chocolate and heavy coffee. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and roasted moderate bitter finish. 120516

From the bottle. Pours black with a small brown head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, nuts and dough. Taste is of dark robust malts, chocolate and bread. Not my favorite style, but this beer is very well crafted. Enjoyable! Thanks Mac!
Draught @ Fools Gold. Dry porter with notes of coffee, licorice and bitter chocolate. Lacks some sweetness.

Bottle courtesy of luttonm, shared in Rome-Italy. Thank you. Dark brown almost black pour, medium foamy head. Nose: the most balanced coffee/chocolate aroma ever, some roasted. Mouth: clean Porter, none of the notes among coffee and chocolate dominate but all are there in armory. Just elegant!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2017 750ml bottle shared by luttonm @Johnnys Off License. Thank you Matt! Pours deep brown/black with a medium and persistent cappuccino head. Aroma is rich and powerful, dark chocolate, gianduja, coffee, licorice... awesome! Flavour is perfectly balanced, medium sweet with a good bitter chocolate end. Medium to full body. Amazing! This beer is a real masterpiece!

bottle to glass. Pours black with tan head. Aroma is bitter chocolate, malt. Taste is bitter, a bit tinny, get dark cocolate after a few sips. Aftertaste lingers bit - bitter chocolate. This is not my personally favorite porter, but its a good beer.

Aroma complejo, notas a chocolate, café, maltas tostadas y algo licorosa.

De color negro con ligeros destellos granates, corona abundante de espuma de excelente retención.

Al paladar es exquisita, equilibrio perfecto, cuerpi ligero, sabor intenso y fácil de tomar.

Al paladar al igual que en aroma una cerveza compleja. Notas a chocolate, café, maltas tostadas, sabor torrefacto y ligeramente ahumado, combinado de forma magistral, dando un equilibrio perfecto.

En pocas palabras la mejor representante del estilo.

Schon ein ordentlicher Hammer an dicker Flüssigkeit und recht bodenständigen Aromen mit einem angenehmen Hintergrund an Kaffee, Getreiden, Malz und Beeren. Schwer und süffig, dabei erwärmend und befriedigend. Top.

Bottle from trade with HenrikO - many thanks! The beer has got a deep black colour with a smooth head and smooth body. Aroma of woods and malt. Taste of intense malt, woods, pine, chocolate, roast and coffee. Dry-roasty and intense finish. Delicious.

Pours coffee brown with a th but serviceable tan head. Aroma presents tempting coffee, roast malt and subtle chocolate tones. Flavor delivers chocolate, molasses, roast malt, toffee and subtle licorice notes. Mouthfeel features firm and smooth yet fizzy body. Enjoy!

Aroma caramel, chocolate, coffee, roasty, 
Appearance black, tan foam, brown foam, 
Taste medium sweetness, 
Palate medium body, full body, 
Overall wow I just happened to be at the right place at the right time and this came onto the draft list. This is the best porter I have had to date. So well balanced. Without a doubt I would suggest this beer to a friend.

Bottle, thanks to Reynolds314. Sampled as part of a porter blind tasting (sample 3 of 6). Creamy head; real sexy, best looker of the group by far. Good lacing and retention. Aroma: dough; roast; caramel; urinal cake. Taste: Very roasty. Also comes with some bandaid/adhesive and lightly metallic overtones. Bummer. Lots of roast and chocolate though -- flavor is robust to say the least; maybe a little too robust. Medium body, not chalky. Thick, makes me think of the latter half of a french press coffee. Overall: I love the appearance and palate. I dislike the taste and aroma. Still most interesting of the night so far.

500 ml bottle shared with friends at the Hoppy Pub, Thessaloniki, from trade with Frank. Black color with beige brown head. Roasted malty aroma, coffee, licorice, chocolate, cocoa, caramel. Sweet and bitter taste like aroma. Oily to full silky body with soft carbonation.

Porter Blind Tasting #3. Biggest head of the blind tasting. Pretty dark brown head. Darkest beer of the blind tasting. First major aspect on the nose is coffee (afterwards, I actually interpreted this as phenolics). Its got some dry bitter leaf, which seems like a hop character. Not strong but the strongest of the blind tasting. Flavor, is clean, similar coffee (phenolyics), light hop bitterness. And again a mild fruity-tutti aspect. Afterward, I was glad to drink this beer and experience it without the hype. Decent stuff but definitely nothing spectacular (as has always been my experience of HF porters/stouts).

text: Poured from bottle into a tulip: This might be the best porter in the world. Pours dark brown with a thin khaki head. Aroma of roasted goodness, earth, leaves, and light cocoa. Flavor is more of the same, very dry, full body, fantastic beer.

500, capped. Consumed in Everett, Washington. Oh, the humanity. Thanks, M! You sure do know how to hook the guys up. Really appreciating all of these. Pours an opaque ebony with a loose, falling light tan head. Beautifully balanced cocoa nose, with soft wood notes, light earth, distant bittersweet chocolate. Creamy thick body with soft carb. Chocolate, cocoa, earth, and roasty malts on the mid palate. Beautifully balanced and coherent, just gorgeous.
Its a really good and really roasty porter. I think I like it less than Ed Fitz and a few others but its still pretty damn great.

Bouttle thanks to trade with bigda83! Pours an opaque black from 500mL with thin lacy brown head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of roasty malt, earthy middle, and dark chocolate undertones. Taste is more toward the chocolate, with a bit of fruity yeast character. Thicker than normal porter, and definitely well done, but not sure its as great as everyone makes it out to be.

Bouteille 500ml, gracieuseté de stoned99, merci Alex! Couleur noire opaque, mousse moka riche et crémeuse. Arôme de chocolat, caramel, malt torréfié, café moka, un peu fruité. Goût de chocolat noir, malt torréfié, café, bonne amertume. Carbonatation moyenne, corps moyen-dense, crémeuse.
500ml bottle from 08/2015. Pours a black color with a small amount of head. Strong hoppiness from start to finish. A little skunky and chocolatey.

Nice roasted malt aroma and flavor. Dry but a slight sweet finish. Almost a cocoa like dryness. Full flavored but light enough to be an easy drinking porter. Slight smoke feel but that might be more the cocoa dryness? Super balanced and an awesome porter. Such a flavorful body but without a sticky palate and super easy drinking for how much flavor it has.

Tap. Nearly black, thin khaki head. Malted milk and toasy chocolate. Flavor is malted milk, chocolate, slight toast. Medium slick body.
This is a really awesome beer. Sweet and chocolatey, with a lot of roasted flavor. Mouthfeel is smooth and full. A near-perfect Porter.
Dark brown color. Medium brown head. Very nice nose of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate malts, slightly smokey. Medium body. Very hoppy. Definitely an American Porter.

Many thanks Will for this treat! Pours an opaque brown with a tan head. The smell is creamy chocolate, roasted malt, mild caramel. The taste is roasted malt, caramel sweetness in the middle ending dry and roasty. full bodied, with elegant carbonation.

Many thanks to ThirstyBird for sharing! The beer starts intense roasted, smooth with sourish porter hints. Lots of chocolate, roasted malt, moderate bitterness. Easy to drink but great fresh and deep. Smooth malty but not too sweetish aftertaste. Nice!
Dark pour with thick caramel head. From a bottle. Malty chocolate smell and taste. Super roasty.

On tap at Mule Bar, Winooski, VT. Clear, dark, cola brown. Thin ring of tan. Aroma of dark chocolate dipped cherries. Dark fruits. Some fruity caramel notes. Taste is fruity and vinous. Light, roast bitterness. Smooth and fairly light bodied. Finishes fruity, woody bitter. Lovely porter.

500 mL bottle. No bottle date. Originally reviewed 6/22/2012/

Pours a black body that is translucent at the edges. Billowing mocha head that almost overflows the glass. Excellent retention and even some nice lacing.

Chocolate and coffee dominate the nose. Some booze, which is surprising for 7.5%. A deep, ashy, almost burnt character persists in the background, perhaps detracting from other aromas.

Coffee and chocolate are the most dominant flavors. It really mirrors the aromas, even in the relative proportions of the flavors. The finish is bitter, but seemingly from that ashy burnt character. Again, its slightly boozy.

I had this on tap and it seemed much heavier and more viscous than it does in the bottle. Its medium bodied, but slick on the tongue. The bitter ashy finish is a little detracting, but otherwise its good.

 I dont find this to be earth-shattering as the reviews suggest. Its still a solid and impressive beer. Yet another technical masterpiece from Hill Farmstead, but lacking in a certain refinement that their other beers have.

Embouteillée en août 2015, bue après 3 mois. Belle robe noire pratiquement opaque. Aucun col de mousse sauf un petit cerne timide autour du verre. Dentelle légèrement huileuse mais un pourrait dire quil ny en a pas. Arômes orientés vers le malt et pain rôtis. Un peu de grains de café, chocolat aux noisettes, mélasse. On perçoit un petite touche de houblon en arrière-plan. Nez intense, complexité moyenne et à limage de ce que peut être un bon porter. En bouche, toujours cette touche de rôti. Par contre des saveurs plus sucrées se dévoilent également. Chocolat noir, anis, caramel, mélasse. Bien malté et légère amertume boisée en finale sur une trame de fond de chocolat et pain rôti. On reste dans un équilibre superbe mariant rôti et sucré. Texture moyenne-epaisse, bon corps envoûtant. Très faible carbonation. Bonne biere.

Bottle courtesy of Jeroen! Poured a murky dark brown with a frothy tan head. The aroma is sweet roasty smoked malt, creamy caramel. The flavour is moderate to light sweet with a rich, chewy roasted sweet malt, coffee, dark chocolate, light alcohol bitter palate and a lingering liqourice bitter finish. Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle shared. Black with nice but short lasting beige head. Nuts, coffee, dark chocolate, light roasted grains, ash, fudge. Towards the finish some nice fresh herbs and a light mineral touch. Medium sweet with roasted bitter finish. Medium bodied with full creamy feel. Great.

Bottle sampled with friends.
Thin tan head. Clear deep amber pour. Very choclatey in the afteraste. A very good porter

[9/25/15] Bottle sample at Borefts Beer Festival 2015 in Bodegraven. Thanks everyone who shared bottles! Black with a tan head. Aroma of roast, coffee, dark fruits. Bittersweet flavor, roasty, with chocolate, coffee, some dark fruits. Full-bodied. Really good.
Bottle shared, thanks. Opaque black color, medium sized light brown head. Smell and taste malts, liquorice, slightly sweetish chocolate, moderately bitter finish.

Bottle at McGillicuddys. Dated 09/07/2015.
This was poured into a tulip, eh, oh well, next time mug, nonic or pint glass.
No worries, I know Sean Hill is anal about stupid shit he doesnt know, eh, whatever.
The appearance was a nice looking dark brown color with a one finger white to off white foamy head that dissipated within less than a minute. Light lacing surrounded the glass, thick yet not too thick as it showed enough spliced delicate thin-ness to it (adequate).
The smell started off with sweet to robust and roasty coffee and cocoa moving slowly into a real nice malty aroma.
The taste rolled into the sweetness nicely with a fairly sweet to roasty with a tad of bitter coffee blending nicely. Theres a nice semi-sweet to roasty aftertaste bleeding into a semi-dry finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium in body with a fairly nice sessionability about it. Carbonation runs nicely underneath fulfilling a fairly light quality but not too light.
Overall, as an American Porter, it works. Its nice and definitely one to have this time of the year.

Poured into a snifter at home. Black liquid with a tan one finger head. Some lace. The aroma is big chocolate, coffee, anise, vanilla, and roasted malts. The tastes are the same as the aromas which is big coffee, chocolate, vanilla, caramel, and anise. Slight dry finish with a burnt malts aftertaste. Moderate to fuller body, creamy, and satisfying. Solid porter!
Runder, dunkel malziger Antrunk. Nicht sonderlich intensiv, würzig, etwas schwach. Okay. 12/9/9/9/12/9
Sehr dunkel orange braunes Bier mit einer mittelgroßen beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch nach Vanille, Kakao, Schokolade. Geschmack süß malzig, Karamell, Vanille, toffee.

Bottle to glass. Pours a deep brown to black with a creamy tan head. Aroma has tons of burnt toast, chocolate, coffee. A little more burnt bitterness in the flavor. Definitely the best non-BA porter Ive had! Thanks Dennis.
Bottle at borefts. Pours black, nose is meaty, smoky, chocolate, taste is similar, dry, roasted, bitter.

Bottle at Borefts Beer Festival courtesy of Thomas (cheer Thomas) De Molen, Bodegraven Friday 25th September 2015 in the company of Jackie and Simon   Black with a light beige head, cappuccino, soft in the mouth this is a really nice beer, smooth and creamy. Sweet malt on the nose, a little malty also in the mouth. Really liked it. A7 A4 T8 P4 Ov15 3.8
Tap. Dark pour with an awesome mocha head. Complex, coffee, chocolate, roast, soil. Well balanced. Medium full body. Silky but flavorful sweet bitter body and long finish. Really really nice

Looks thick as it pours. Dark brown, with an intense brown-read head. The aroma is really great. Coffee, molasses, chocolate, fresh soil. Taste is moderately sweet and a tad bitter. A very well-crafted porter.

Bottle shared by JulienHuxxley, with Borresteijn. Black color. Big beige head, a bit frothy. Aromas of roast, (ground) coffee, chocolate, mocha and light red fruit. Flavor is roasty sweet, roasty bitterish. Body is medium to full. Lots of roast and moderate bitter finish. Lovely stuff!

50cl Bottle, thanks Julien! Black colour, beige head. Aroma of roast, burnt malts, chocolate, red fruits, gets sweeter when it warms. Flavour is medium sweet, roasted malts, red fruits, Belgian chocolate, bittersweet finish. Light to medium bodied. Nice.

Bottle shared by Bartlebier @ 3/4 Dangerous Bottle Shares meets Moules Frites. Nose has layers of roast, coffee and some dark chocolates. Taste is smooth with a large dose of roast upfront. As it warms up it balances out with tons of dark chocolate on the backend. Long finish...

Probada en Top Hops, Lower East Side, New York. Chocolate, Tabaco y madera en la fusión perfecta. Una porter americana inigualable.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

When you think of Hill Farmstead, you probably think of IPAs and saisons, but they do make a wide variety of styles including porter. This is my first dark beer from this highly sought-after brewery and its definitely an excellent example of the style. Robust palette with a body thats as nice on the eyes as it is on the tongue. 

I poured a 500ml bottle into a tulip glass. It was bottled on 8/14/15 and cost $8.50 ($0.50 per ounce). Thanks to Jon H. for the bottle!

Appearance: One of the darkest porters Ive seen with a jet black, opaque hue with just a hint of brown highlights. Pours to a large, dark tan frothy head which retains and laces extremely well.

Smell: Plenty of dark malt, though not roasty or chocolaty per se. Fairly sweet scent all around with a trace of pine.

Taste: Theres a fine line between a strong robust porter and a stout and Everett seems to straddle that line pretty firmly. I dont get the lighter fruity sweetness here thats typical of a porter, but more of a deeply bitter roasty sensation usually associated with stouts. Not that Im complaining, but the flavors that are present are plenty delectable. Sweet dark malty flavor is the first component, followed by a resiny/piney sensation from the hops. Not especially bitter, though there is a dry, coffee and burnt toast-like taste on the finish. A residual earthy aftertaste completes and complements the palette perfectly. 

Drinkability: Hill Farmstead Everett is not only a great-tasting beer, its also a pleasure to drink. The mouthfeel is very silky and smooth, though it does feel just a tad thin. For a 7.2% ABV brew, there is no alcohol presence whatsoever; which makes it almost dangerously drinkable. Even the aftertaste is good, if a bit astringent but easily tolerable.

RATING: 9/10

750 ml growler shared with Alex and Seb A: chocolate, tobacco, light roastiness, light caramel. App: pitch black minimal beige head. T/p: med to full body with moderate long bitter finish. O: A great complexity with nice overall smoothness. Been a while since I had such a balanced porter.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2015 750ml 1 week fresh growler from the brewery shared with Jo and Seb. Aroma: rosted malt, chocolate, wood, tobacco. App: dark brown, even burgundy, small brown head. Taste and palate: full body, creamy, average carbonation, smooth, medium bitter finish. Overall: great. Really smooth. Enjoyed the bitter finish. Will sure buy again

Liquide bien foncé qui génère une mini mousse dorée et très crémeuse. On sent le caramel, les noisettes et le café. En bouche limpression est bien ronde, on dirait prèsquun sirop, à cette légère différence quune bouteille de sirop ne me donne pas envie de la boire en entier! Les bières foncées et/ou sucrées ne sont pas celles que je préfère, mais japprécie toujours, malgré tout, lorsque la bière est bien brassée. Et cest clairement le cas ici. Hill Farmstead rate rarement sa cible... Une bière parfaite pour les amateurs du style!

Bottle. Pours pitch black with a big dark brown head. Aromas of dark roast, bitter chocolate, caramel, dust, malts, light smokiness, dark fruits. Taste is dark chocolate, roast, caramel, tobacco, liceorice, light smokiness, dry wood, dark sweet fruits. Damn classy smooth porter!

Tasted from draft. Pours black with a beige soda like head. Aroma is dark chocolate, coffee, and tobacco. Taste is moderately bitter with mild malty sweet backbone. Flavors of coffee, chocolate, caramel, toffee, and licorice. Pretty full bodied. Excellent porter.

Poured from growler thanks Willrunforbeer. Dark chocolate pour with a nice ftothy tan head. Aromas of chocolate roasted malt and coffee. Taste is smooth and sweet with a nice mouth feel. Notes of coffee chocolate and vanilla. This is an excellent beer.

Growler rapporté de la brasserie et dégusté en compagnie de Mademoiselle Irina. Bière très sombre et mousseuse décorant les parois de mon verre de dentelles et de picots blancs sur fond noir. Un dalmatien vu en négatif! Nez complexe de café Jamaïcain amer, dune gousse de vanille naturelle, de cacao et de céréales bien grillées-torréfiées mais non brûlées. Cest à la fois subtil, séduisant et viril. En bouche, beaucoup damertume de café. Les grains rôtis ayant libéré un sucre résiduel non négligeable, cette bière est ronde et soyeuse, tout en étant dune impressionnante légèreté! Une magnifique pétillance vient titiller le bout de ma langue qui fourche à chaque gorgée tellement ce que je déguste en ce moment est complexe. La poudre de cacao. Oui une poudre dune chocolat noir de qualité exceptionnel à 99% de cacao sans le côté râpeux. Dune longueur presque infinie, la bière coule doucement dans mon oesophage admiratif, laissant derrière elle, ma bouche satinée et dans lattente de la prochaine gorgée. Peu de gens peuvent encore se vanter davoir connu le frère Everett du grand-père de la famille, mais il doit être fier, là où il repose, quune telle bière fut brassée en hommage à sa mémoire!
Pours black with a frothy tan head. Aromas of roasted malt, coffee and alcohol. Tastes of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. I can taste the alcohol but it has a warming feel to it. Full bodied.

The Farmhouse, Burlington, VT, draft. Blackity-black. Dark tan, creamy head. No lacing. Strong coffee with dark chocolate. Sticks around on the palate a long time. Thick.

Jan tasting with the crew. Hint of oxidation on this one, but not detracting at all. Bits of char, bold, roast, toffee, complex, thick molassess. Nice.
Bottle with the crew. Big roasty malt and bittersweet coffee. Berry and cherry aroma. Bit of a burned malt character. Wood and earth texture. Complex and smooth like every hill beer.
Bottle shared at Capitol Beer & Tap Room. Pours near black with a nice tan head and a marvelous treacle aroma. There is a hearty dark molasses flavor with some coffee and chocolate. Very tadty.

Pours a deep black with a small but well retained head and nice lacing on the glass.

The aroma is lightly sweet & very rich with nice roasty/chocolaty notes. The hoppiness is mild but noticeable throughout. 

The flavor is a little ashy with lots of roasty malt. Its got a nice hop flavor which lends to some bitterness but more of that seems derived from the roasty malt character. The beer has some berry and dried fruit fruitiness that ties in well with everything else going on. 

Geeze Louise its nice porter, sheesh!

Sample at Jackie Os during the 9th Anniversary Extravaganza on 12/05/14. Opaque brown-black color with a medium foamy tan head that diminishes gradually to a film. Patchy lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt, dark chocolate and hops. Medium creamy body with flavors of charred malt, bittersweet chocolate, coffee and earthy hops. The finish is roasty with a chocolate malt aftertaste. Growler shared by yourefragile, thanks Moll. Pours a dark brown/near black with dark cherry hues when backlit. Head fades quickly to edge with spotty lacing. cocoa a bit gritty and with some smoke. medium body somewhat chewy and not too heavy on pine or malt. some roast in there,
Draft. Pours black. Aroma and taste are roasted malts, chocolate, and coffee.

At my place with Taylor, Justin, Kristen, Matt, Jacob, Jen, other Matt. Pours black with lacing. Aroma is smooth bourbon, complex barrel, interesting and nice. Taste is so tasty, smooth interesting malts, chocolate, warm booze.

Growler from brewery. Pours black with a creamy thin tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee and had a hint of caramel. This is not as good as the ratings imply. It's a fair porter but to be honest, it tastes like my homebrewed porter. Not really that impressed after seeing the rating.

NOSE: coffee, chocolate, vanilla.

Bottle from cpetrone-huge thanks for my first HF, Chris!! Incredibly dark porter, with sparse dark brown coffee crema head. Outstanding porter. So silky. Black pour. Nose of espresso, chocolate, and slight bittering hops. Taste followed with added smokiness, but was absolutely smooth and rich. Perfect level of carbonation. Fantastic.

Courtesy of OHLRangers
Growler: The aroma consists of dark chocolate, roasted malt, black licorice, espresso, and some faint burnt notes. The finish espresso, light vanilla, and a touch of burnt notes. Its medium bodied with light-moderate carbonation.
Draft, pours black with a beige head. Aroma of chocolate and some coffee. Dark chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts in the flavor. Thin body, smooth. Awesome beer

A slender and silky belgian androgyne. Soft wet hay. A faint memory of apricot.

2 oz. tasting glass at brewery. Espresso nose with rich milk froth head. Silky coffee chocolate notes and tight carbonated feel.  Hard to imagine what a better porter would taste like.

Dark brown, sort of clear. Deep earthy, coffee notes, grains. Some bitter dark chocolate notes. Thick body, heavy mouthfeel. Lighter carbonation. Really well awesome.

Pours black with a creamy beige long lasting head that leaves good lacing. Flavor is rich chocolate, toffee and like they say, malty sweetness. balanced. Excellent

From a growler shared by Adam Jackson. Pours black with a thin khaki head which disappears quickly. Aroma speaks of light coffee with cream, caramel and chocolate. Flavor is milk chocolate, more light coffee, a little roast and just a kiss of earthy hops. Medium to heavy body and smoooooth! Thanks Adam for sharing this.

From a growler. Thanks Adam. The pour is nearly black with a modest tan head. Opaque. The aroma has a good dark malt and chocolate note going on. Thin to medium body but smooth. The taste also has a wonderful dark malt and chocolate flavor. The beer lives up to ts reputation.
On draft at Prohibition Pig. Dark brown pour with no head. Roasted malt nose. Chocolate roasted malt and a nice hop background. A touch of heat in the finish. Yummy.
Bouteille 500 mL. Brune opaque à mousse brune pâle. Belle présence en bouche, sans être tapissante. Pain grillé, espresso et chocolat cacao 100%. Belle porter, encore plus agréable en fût selon moi.

Small pour at Brouwerij Lane. Nearly black with small tan head. Aroma is unreal coffee, Valrhona chocolate, prunes, marshmallow, roasted grain, stewed cherries, hazelnut. Taste is coffee and bitter chocolate with a pronounced almond praline sweetness balanced by hop bitterness. So smooth and rich, yet not over the top. Insanely good porter and deserving of the hype.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2015 Bottle shared at the 2014 tasting in the Cellar of Moeder Lambic Saint-Gilles. Pours near black with a small tan head. Aroma of roast, milk chocolate, caramel, light coffee and dough. Flavour is over moderate sweet and moderate bitter. Over medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Aroma: caramel, chocolate, coffee, earthy, smoke
Appearance: black, very black, as in oily and almost sinister, light-will-not-pass-through BLACK
Taste: heavy cloying sweetness(for a porter, In my experience so far), medium bitterness, and though the definition of "taste" here does not include smoke, I can only conclude that either people like have mutant tastebuds which can sense smokiness, or, more likely, It really really is that smoky.
Most full, complex mouthfeel & aftertaste Ive had next to weizenbock.
I feel very privileged to live less than 2hrs. drive from the brewery, and wish them all the success they deserve for producing such wonderful beer.

Bottle from trade. Pours black with decent tan head. Aroma is coffee first, then some cocoa, vanilla. Taste is just amazing - I was shocked at the medium-full body of this beer when its only 7.5%. Just a great, nicely rounded combination of chocolate, coffee, caramel, maybe a bit of licorice. One of the finer porters Ive had.

A porter from Hills Farmstead, who knew? Shared by Rei on the occasion of Hypo Luxa heading back to the US. Drunk from a Mikkeller tulip glass. Inky black pour with a thin lingering tan head. Rich coffee with some roastiness. Light bodied, very roasty coffee flavor. Very soft smooth mouthfeel but a bit on the light side. Not complex but incredibly solid.

Bottle and aged about a year. 
Aroma is sweet raisins. 
Light bodied. Coffee and very light vanilla. Liquid smoke. Mocha. 
Something more there but can find it. 
Would like to try this on tap.
UPDATED: MAY 28, 2014 Bottle pours black with low head and carb. Aroma is roast and pine with coffee and chocolate notes. Taste is similar, lots of chocolate and bitter finish

Pour is dark brown, almost black, with a thin coffee brown ring. Nose is roasted barley, cocoa, hint of roasted coffee and a bit dusty. Taste has more malt sweetness, lightly roasted barley with strong cocoa, coffee lingers in finish. Full bodies, smooth and creamy with strong carbonation. There is more malt sweetness in the taste, towards the back of the palate adding some nice depth.

Draft. Pours black with thick creme white head. Smells of sweet coffee/chocolate with little carbonation. Substantial with chocolate and coffee flavors.

Deep black with a small tan head. Fairly flat. Nose was Roasted malts coffee,chocolate, caramel. Hops hidden behind the roastiness. Smooth body. Lovely smooth finish. Now thats a porter.

Found on tap at GoodBeer NYC

Tasting notes from 12/6/12

Oil black with a small tan head. Little carbonation, just enough. Roasted coffee, banana, burnt sugar, vanilla maybe. Some resiny hop character in the taste. Finish is velvety.

Tap at the Jeffrey. Pours dark brown with not too large of head. Nose of cocoa and dark fruit. Tastes of dark chocolate, raisins, toasted malt, graham crackers, and soy sauce. Creamy palate with nice carbonation to at some zing. Lingering palate of chocolate. Nice to see HF back in city
Pours a dark brown with a cappuccino colored lacing. Notes of chocolate, some soy and vanilla

Dark brown with a good light chocolate head. Bottle was a bit of a gusher. Aroma is chocolate, roasted cashews, coffee, dates, graham cracker. Slightly creamy mouthfeel, full bodied, roasty on the palate with some good balancing malt. Taste is coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, hint of oak. Nice

Had on draft at CCB Brewpub in Tampa(!). I don't know how they got it, but I'm thankful they did. Typical black pour with an inviting, roasty aroma. The mouthfeel on this is amazing. Viscous without being syrupy, I've never encountered a texture this velvety on a porter before. It seriously had the feel of a quality barrel aged imperial stout. The taste was equally impressive. Sweeter than most other porters with a moderate roastiness and hippiness. Just an exquisitely balanced beer. Best porter I've ever had.

Bottle to tulip
Loads of caramel, coffee, blackstrap molasses, some chocolate
Deep black with a thin creamy tan head
The taste is roasted malt and coffee, some chocolate.
This is very smooth and well balanced.

Bottle - Roast malts, chocolate and the slightest soy. Jet black with a rich brown head. Roasted malts with a tiny bit of chocolate and a roast finish. A great porter where the malts are the king. Great to see a classic so well and simply done.

So robust. Lots of chocolate and coffee with a creamy soft body and not bittery harshness.

Draft. Black pour, tan head, good retention, some lace. Aroma of dark chocolate, roast, espresso. Taste is lightly bitter, big dark chocolate, espresso. Palate is soft, slick, light bitter finish. Very good.

Bottle courtesy jcvanderbilt. Pours pretty near to black with a creamy cocoa head. Soft, sweet aroma with forward notes of milk chocolate and caramel, slight lactose, slight sawdust. Flavor is really potent and deep, bright up front with fresh-brewed espresso and then transforming into a long chocolate-anise denseness to finish. Subtle accents of smoke, burnt bread, and molasses, plus a lingering zest like eating roasted coffee beans. Thick, silky body with low carbonation. This one really pushes the limits of how good a straight-up porter can be. Luscious stuff.
Dark brown pour, tan head. Nose is chocolate, slight espresso, roasted malts. Taste is chocolate, roasted malts, marshmallow, fresh water. Medium-full bodied. Sticky and smooth mouthfeel.

Bottled: unk

Pours a nice black with a sheet of mocha foam. Smells robust son! Chocolate, coffee, roasted barley, coffee (faint), cocoa powder, graham and more toasted malts. Flavor follows suit with a good earthy roasted character, a strong cocoa flavor, nice bits of coffee nib, and a sweetness Im surprised at that is transient in nature and does not linger. Great flavor. Full bodied with tight and sharp carb loosely scattered, this leaves your mouth coated and satisfied, yet wanton for the next sip. This is a world class beer, and I think the best porter Ive ever had. Sincerely wish I had a clone recipe.

Serving type: bottle

10-04-2012
Bottle pour. This Hill Farmstead brew is all its cracked up to be. The best porter Ive ever had. Strong chocolate aromas with silky smooth flavors of coffee and vanilla.

Bottle. Opaque black body. Brown head. Big aroma of roasted malts, caramel, chocolate, tobacco. Hint of coffee and pine and dark fruit. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, velvety texture, soft carbonation. Rich and complex with lots of flavor: Coffee, roasted grain, pine, caramel. Hint of herbs.
Big thanks to tectactoe. My first from the brewery and I was not let down. Huge milk chocolate taste and feel. Really really good. Perfect alcohol background.

500 ml...wish it was a liter bottle thanks to bytemesis . Pours a awe inspiring jet black color with a large tan mocha head. A rich nose of chocolate, lactose, big caramel. Big flavor abound with mocha, caramel, dark fruit, woody, some yeasty dry flavors, big sweetness almost balanced by bitter metallic roast and milky lactose. Lovely art here. This is a hefty brew, and brings the total package. Umm. Awesome. Roast and sweet caramel in the finish. A bit like a Baltic Porter, anise and licorice evident. Wonderful.

Poured from a bottle into a Spiegelau tulip. From notes, July 26, 2012. 

A: Roasted coffee, chocolate, toasted malt and white bread crust.
A: Pours deep brown, practically black, with a nice one and a half finger width mocha-colored head leaving thin trails of lace down parts of the glass. 
T: Follows the nose with smokey roasted chocolate. Toffee, light caramel and plenty of dry dark/raw chocolate with a smooth chocolatey finish. The beer is not very complex, but its a luscious symphony of creamy chocolate flavors throughout. 
P: As with all Hill Farmstead beers, the mouth-feel is very near perfect. Medium bodied with creamy carbonation. 
O: Worldclass for sure. Fantastic flavor profile, complimented immensely by the rich mouth-feel. Quite possibly the best porter on the planet.

2L growler, pours dark brown, black in glass with big fluffy gorgeous mocha head. Nose is bitter roasty coffee and dark chocolate. Mouthfeel is full bodied, rich, creamy. Taste is big roasted coffee, chocolate, cream. Finish is coffee, sweet malty notes, some nuttiness. Easily the best porter Ive tried so far. Amazing. (From 11/15 notes)

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2014 Bottle: Thanks to LostGringo! Super dark, almost completely back with a nice layer of mocha-tan foam that settles to a nice collar. Aroma is milky chocolates, smooth roast, light coffee, a mild underlying sweetness, a touch of borderline campfire smokiness, & a beautiful, nutty finish. Robust & roasty with a smooth, creamy sweetness undercurrent that balances perfectly. Without question, one of the finest porters Ive had to date. Balanced so well.

From bomber.

growler, possibly the best porter that ive had to date. black black pour, very roasty & chocolatety, pretty bitter. fuller mouthfeel. another winner from HF

Bottle share by Chris, Big roasted malt, chalky coffee roast. Similar taste, nice hops in the finish, nice body.

text: 10th January 2013Opaque black - brown beer, big fluffy tan head. Softish palate, light and airy. Light touch of dark malt with a good streak of medium chocolate (ie not dark and not milk). Super light roast. Very modest citric hop provides a counterpoint. Trace of red berry fruits. Airy finish. Pretty fine porter. LIght and super drinkable.

The booze is present but melds exceedingly well. The finish is dryish but still sweet. A delightful treat and one of the best porters Ive EVER had.

In the late summer of this year, I lived in a house in a subdivision that looked across the swamp and the plain to the hills. I came across this beer that locals called Everett. A special mans grandfathers brother was Everett, much like this beer. I never had the chance of knowing the man, but his legacy and words will be carried, in a way, through a creation of love that bears his name. He was strong, with lots of siblings. The nose of this beer, like the man not known to you and me, has many layers. Like siblings oft-do, playing well with each-other, only to build off their strengths. It soon comes to pass, that many realize their force is greater combines than to work against each other. Some notes to be imagined, some to be grasped, like hands clenching the tools of the field. Strong hands, hard work. Strong chocolate and bitter. But not bitter in the way of wrath, but rather firm, like the hands of an old soul. This beer, like the man our minds have come to know, has a strong foundation. Sturdy feet, that have known the tasks and toils of yesteryear. A man of such traditions, must stand firm, but show the softer side for the ones that are loved. The coffee notes are reminiscent of the first cup before a long days work. The liquid libation that is needed when there is a long day ahead, and many more after that. The water in this bottle tastes not like that of any regions yonder, but of natural water, from the earth, that has seen many cycles and will continue to do so, in many forms. This beer will not be with us just today, but will continue the cycle once again, and once again. The sweetness of this beer is one that can be imagined like the man in our minds. Only after he warms up to you, does this soft, sweeter side come to shine. A side well guarded, and for good measure. For lest we know the effort that hast gone into creating such a crafted soul. As it is tasted, the senses of caramel, toffee, and the smaller joys of life come through. A beer of many layers and mystery. The German and English malts play upon each others strengths; it was not always the case throughout humanity, but save Everett, it has come to show us, the harmony of the ways. As the beer begins to fade into the hills and no longer with us, it leaves behind a drying finish. One that can only leave you to wish there was more time to be spent with it here. But the impression it leaves will be with you always. There will always be a bit of Everett once it has come into your life. And to know the best side is to know the only side of the beer created in a great mans honor. After a while I went out and left the place and walked back to the hotel in the rain. When asked about this beer and the impression it leaves, I have only to say, Yes, Isnt it pretty to think so?

Bottle shared with the group. Pours dark brown in color with a small creamy beige head. The aroma has big roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, some sweet cream with a hint of molasses. The flavor has more roasted malts, chocolate, coffee with some sweeter notes, dark fruit and some molasses. This is one of the best porters Ive had.
Shared with timfoolery. Great roasty porter with chocolate, toffee, and coffee flavors.
UPDATED: JUL 24, 2013 Best porter I?ve had. Has a strong coffee aroma. Tastes coffee like with an earthy taste to it. Fantastic beer.

Bottle purchased at the brewery on 7/6/13 and opened that night in the hotel. Darkest brown in color with a thick light brown head. Malty and chocolatey nose with cream and coffee notes. Malty flavor with plenty of chocolate and coffee accents along with some creaminess before a roasty, bitter finish. Even with all the big robust flavors, the body of the beer justifies it being called a porter and not a stout. Very well done.
500 ml. bottle. Thanks Mike! Pours almost black with a small tan head. Aroma of roast, coffee, and chocolate. Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, vanilla, and molasses. A true delight!
growler at chopkofest. lots of roast and smoke. medium chocolate. pine on the finish. body is solid, mealy and chewy. a great porter.

Bottle from HF trade. Aroma is more caramel, while flavor seems more chocolate and light roast. Palate is smooth on front end, bitter espresso on back end. Very good beer.

Bottle with Timfoolery at tasting, a really good porter, not thin, sweet with slight bitterness.
