Very black color, plenty of brownish, creamy head. Chocolate, some coffee, vanilla aroma. Slightly sweet chocolate flavor hits my palate first followed by a slow transition to roasty bitterness. Some tobacco. Creamy feel. Really great flavor, like a big stout but without the ABV. Awesome porter.

Growler. Pours deep nearly opaque brown to black, medium brown creamy head that dissipates slowly with great lacing. Assertions is coffee, roasted malt, cigarettes, anise. Flavor is very rich,, including chocolate, a touch of anise, molasses. Light sweetness, medium bitterness. Full body, creamy mouthfeel.

Growler thanks Tom. Pours a very dark brown with small tan head that quickly diminishes to nothing. The aroma is a strong roast, chocolate, coffee, and nutmeg. Medium mouthfeel with a sweet roasted chocolate and nice light bitterness in the finish. So easy to drink, a very impressive porter from HF.

On tap. Pours pitch black with little head. Strong notes of coffee and beans. Incredibly smooth for a porter, with a little bite. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

$7 at Three Penny. To bulbous tulip, it pours a dark, vinegary brown, presenting an off-khaki head 1 finger in length. Smells and tastes fittingly of chocolate almond milk, Kaffir limes, cocoa, cinnamon sticks, vanilla beans, and rum raisin ice cream. Algae, soil, mildew, roast, and marshmallows by swallow. Good stuff.

My 600th rating. Thanks to SlovakSniper for the trade! Pours black with thin foamy tan head. Aroma of sherry, roasted barley, chocolate, and molasses. Taste has chocolate, a big roasty flavour, slight fruit/floral notes, molasses and spice, with a bitter finish. Nice full body, smooth mouthfeel. My first beer from Hill Farmstead; not a disappointment.

Had initially as a taster at the brewery and refined my notes after working my way through a growler over a few days. A robust american porter - coffee and dark chocolate and nutmeg, very light head, light lacing, smooth and very drinkable.

Beautiful aroma of silky sherry and chocolate with roasty grain. Malty flavor with black patent in the background. Sweet with coffee bitterness. Full body with little trace of the alcohol. Thanks to kevinsenn for the share.
Smooth, roasty, delicious... It was hard not to slam the whole bottle at once.  Super sexy looking too with a nice tan head.  Much thanks to jsbilk for this one.

Bottle.  Huge thanks to mikem409 for this one!  Pours black with a medium light brown head.  Aroma is milk chocolate, coffee, roasted grain.  Taste is medium sweet, with both a roasted and hoppy bitterness.  Nice roasty finish.  Incredible smooth mouth feel, soft carbonation.  This is an excellent porter.

Bottle.  Dark brown with a mocha head.  Nice roasted malt aromas.  Easy drinking with a really good mouthfeel and body.  Rich roasted malt notes with mellow caramel, chocolate, toffee, and expresso undertones.  Honestly, I prefer an imperial stout to a porter 99 out of 100 times.  However, this is a very fine ale and an exception to the rule.  One quick side note, this bottle had a bit of age on it so the hop characteristics were diminished.  This is one HF beer that lives up to the hype...
Bottle. Black beer with a small tanned head. Chocolate, vanilla and lot off coffee aroma. Vanilla, chocolate, coffee. a bit tar, malty and roasted flavour,. A lovely beer :-)

750 ml growler from trade with 46er3498.  Pours black with a small foamy head that fades quickly, leaves light oily webbing.  Complex aroma of medium roasted coffee, chocolate, lactose sweetness, lightly charred wood, caramel, light smoke, and a light fruitiness too.  Taste is very sweet for the usual porter.  Has a milk stout quality to it.  Nice coffee, caramel, and chocolate flavors.  Finish is very smooth.  Thin to medium body, mouthfeel is a little oily and very smooth.  Overall, great rich flavors here.  My one complaint is that its a little too sweet.  Would definitely like some more bitterness or roast to balance the sweetness.

November 2, 2012 - with blankboy, gregclow, jercraigs & mabel - 750ml swing-top shared by J&K. Black pour with ruby highlights, average bubbly tan/light brown head.  Aroma is dry, nutty, lush, a bit of limestone mineral tang, lots and lots of low-level hopppzzz, even milky and minty - a spectacular smelling porter, and not over the top with the hops (apparently at this point I was making a series of "O!" faces).  Taste - follows, almost as good as it smells - dry, roasty, hint of tart fruit.  Slick, average carbonation and body, finishes dry and malty and a little earthy - yummy.

Thanks to Jason for the growler. Poured into Bruery tulip.

Pours black, huge mocha-colored head, thick bubbly cap, nice thick lacing. Really, a beautiful-looking beer.  Nose is dark chocolate, slight smoke, oak/woody, nice hoppy notes.  Flavor is similar to the nose, but even better. Nice bitter dark chocolate, molasses, creamy sweetness. Hard to express how delicious this one is.  Medium body, rich and smooth, creamy finish. 

Overall, this beer doesnt try to be anything but a phenomenal porter. Very straight forward and right on the spot. If youre reading this Shaun, great job on this one. A must-try.

Pours a dark brown near black with beige head and little lacing. Aroma of roasted malts, caramel, litle coffee, hops. Taste is all those but hops are more present than the nose, light vanilla notes. Medium to full body and medium to low carb. Best porter i have had yet.

500ml bottle. Thanks Pat! Pitch black pour, with a nice finger of head. The smell is chocolate, coffee, and hint of sweetness. Wow, taste is full of chocolate, vanilla and has a great smooth finish. Excellent!!

Pours a jet black color with a slight mocha head. Smell is chocolate, caramel malts, coffee, and slight vanilla. Taste is awesome, unsweetened cocoa, caramel, vanilla undertones and a little hop bitterness. Coats the palette but finishes dry. Fantastic porter.

On tap at Iron Abbey in Horsham, PA. Had nothing to do on my lunch break so I figured I'd swing by to see what was on tap. I sit at the bar and the bartender says "You look like you want a Hill Farmstead." The answer was obviously a pleasantly surprised "yes" and I got to enjoy this dangerously drinkable, balanced porter. Chocolate and caramel notes come through nicely, and the mouthfeel is just right. Near perfect.

Honestly dont know if its possible for a porter to be better than this.  Black in color with creamy brown head and lacing.  Huge chocolate and coffee aroma/flavor.  A slight whiskey and vanilla undertone comes through as well as it warms.  LOVE THIS!

Bottle, 05/13/2013. Pours black, creamy, dense light tan head with  great retention. Aroma has big cloudy yeast to begin with, then into the more classic porter notes: chocolate brownie, very dark, roasted malts, coffee finish, a lot of depth. Taste is rich, chocolate mousse, softer roast component than the nose, vanilla, hoppy bitterness in a dry finish. Body is full, super creamy, one of the standout features. Took me a bit by surprise, very nice is an understatement.

Thanks to Tommy for the bottle! 2013. Aroma has notes of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, citrus hops and toast. Very nice nose. Pitch black with an average light tan frothy head that really wanted to stick around and left good lace. Flavor is medium sweet and medium/heavy bitter. Palate is full bodied and oily soft with a medium finish. Overall a real surprise. Easily a top 3 porter for me - Id need side-by-side to rank which is the best. Fantastic beer! Loved it.
Great coffee aroma. Great taste with just the right bite. Missing a little of the silky mouthfeel in done porters that I love, but otherwise a perfect example of that style.

Shared bomber at PUBR headquarters.  Poured dark brown withtan head that laced well.  Nose is roasty choc malt, cacao, chocoff, hops. Complex taste and finish, with a well-balanced flavor of upfront roasty dark malt, cacao, yeast, and hops.  I like to call this a Belgian Imperial porter.

Finally, I get to try a bead from HF.  Pour is black with a nice size brown head.  The nose is big roasted coffee, nutty, some light chocolate and a little smoke.  The taste is a very balanced bittersweet through the end.  The texture is soft, smooth, body is medium and the finish is long.  Very good.

Bottle; Pour is dark brown with a two finger fine bubbled khaki head in this glass ; I thought the appearance was perfect. Retention is above average in this glass, with above average lacing here; the nose is chocolate morsels, anise, roasted coffee bean. At this point, its easily my favorite porter. Bittering hops blend seamlessly into the malt profile initial;  more chocolate morsels and a touch of cake here. roasted coffee, light caramel, with a silky mouth feel here, moving to a touch of bitterness near the finish - A great brew.

500mL bottle shared among friends at Original Gravity in San Jose. Big thanks to Seth for this one! Poured into a mini snifter glass. Escapes the bottle with a thick and oily viscosity. This batch does not appear to be very well carbonated. No head, some spotty bubbles here and there. Swirling the beer around leaves noticeable legs and no lacing. Aroma is stout-like, with lots of roasted malts, a touch of smoke/ash and faint chocolate and dark fruits hiding in there. Still very inviting. Taste is exceptional, with all that roast, sweet chocolate, smoke and coffee working together to create a perfect blend of mocha like creme brûlée with a smooth and silky finish. I was prepared for the finish to be more bitter, but instead am taken aback by how smooth and balanced this beer is. Lots of silky milk chocolate, mocha, honey, and almost nutty with a nice alcohol warmth. The body is again, perfect like all the rest of the HF beers. Carbonation is really low, but doesnt seem to affect the taste or feel of the beer at all. After taste is yet again, more of the same honey-like mocha sweetness that isnt overpowering because it is well balanced by the roasted and smokey malts. Exceptional porter and by the far the best Ive ever had. This beer is no joke.

From a 750ml growler. S: The smell its strong on this one, almost like a BA beer, I get dark chocolate, chared, a deep roast, oak nuts and some hops. A: Almost completly black, if you hold it up the light the only red highlight is between the foam and black liquid. This has a nice thick brown head about an inch. T: this is just smooth, giving you mouth chocolate, almonts, dark roast, charred, ending with some marshmallow, and in the back of the throat you get some piney hops which was a little bit weird. The hops killed this beer a bit. M: Pretty much medium all the way. O: A great porter, a style I dont acutually drink to much unless its an imperial, but those hops just kind of killed it in here.

Dégustée en fût au Farmhouse Tap & Grill à Burlington, VT. De couleur brune très foncée et opaque. Nez de malt rôti aux notes brûlées,  léger de café, de chocolat, de mélasse et de houblon herbeux avec des notes de toffee et de pain grillé.  Moyenne-ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen-doux ainsi quune texture moyennement crémeuse. Goût dun mélange de chocolat au lait et de chocolat noir avec des notes de mélasse et de fumée (tourbe) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût de malt rôti et légèrement brûlé avec un léger goût de pain grillé ainsi que des traces de toffee puis en finale lon retrouve une légère amertume de houblon herbeux avec un léger goût de café. Post-goût moyen-long, légèrement amer de rôti,  de houblon herbeux avec des notes de café et quelques traces fumées. (17 avril 2013)
500 ml bottle shared by jsprime. Black with a tan. This is the perfect American porter. Huge complex dark malt body with ample hopping in the aroma and flavour. Just a wonderful beer.
Opaque brown with a thick tan head.  Chocolate, coffee, and roasted grains on the nose. Super full bodied, smooth, a truly memorable glass.

this is an amazing porter easily the best i have had. It has a tan head and lacing that coats the glass nicely. the smell is of roasted coffee, earthy, roasted malt. the mouthfeel is smooth like silk, very full bodied, it coats your mouth. very good!

On tap at Torst.  My maiden beer there.  Pours a dark brown cloudy color with a caramel colored head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate, caramel, alcohol and slight slight spice.  Sweet creamy chocolate taste with coffee notes and slight spice pinch.  Perhaps a slight vanilla to add silkiness.  Love it.  Best porter I have had.  It gets as close to a stout as a porter will get without crossing the line.

Bottle shared by Drew, thanks! Pours a near black with a brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a nice a good amount of roasted malts with some dark grains and a hint of dark fruit. Flavor has a decent amount of roasted with a bit of light chocolate, dark grains and backing light dark fruit.

Bottle from gnosis.. thanks.. Pour is black with a brown head. Lots of it. Chocolate, roasted malt, some light hops on the nose. Taste is diviine... semi-sweet chocolate, some light hoppiness, wood, some smoke, and some bitter coffee. Great balance. Creamy smooth mouthfeel with light carbonation. Same resiny texture as Jimmy. Real winner. Best porter Ive had.

Amazing thick pour for a porter.  Nice smell of smoke and malts.  The palate is balanced damn well.  Taste is thick and full of malt and just the right amount of smoke.  Mouthfeel is thick, one of the best I have ever tried.

500ml bottle.  Black pour with decent mocha head and some impressive cling for the style.  Beautiful beer. Nose is very roasty with plenty of dark chocolate and coffee like characteristics.  Taste is a heavy shot of roast, with coffee, dark chocolate, and a touch of smokiness.  Very nice on  the palate.  Oily and creamy.  One of the best in this style for sure.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle - thanks, Miller! Straight up one of the finest porters Ive had in recent memory. Firm, hefty-looking dark brown pour with a nice firm beige head. Consistent carbonation, nicely sticky lacing, and a rich, silken mouthfeel capped off by an enjoyable chalky finish. Richly flavorful, its the kind of hoppy porter that isnt so overly hopped that it loses the substance and personality one craves from the style. Chocolatey, roasty, with just a faint touch of dark fruits. Elegant and just superbly done.
great porter, a bit stronger than I typically prefer, but it goes down without a hitch.  Slight roast, leather, bitter chocolate, with a subtle chocolatey sweetness in the finish.  perfect mouthfeel.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2013 Draught at George Keelys NYC.  Pours dark brown with a creamy mocha head.  Aroma is of chocolate and espresso. Taste is slightly bitter: roasted coffee and malts as well as chocolate and some dark fruit/ The finish is smooth and the bitterness does not linger.  Really nice.

500 mL bottle, served in a stem glass at a tasting at Gregs. Pours black with a medium tan head that fades to a thin cover, leaving a small amount of lace. On the nose there are notes of smoke, molasses, roasted malts, along with earth and hops. The flavour is mostly dry, with smoky malts, subtle earthy and herbal notes. The finish is long and herbal with subtle smoke. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, milky texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a nice porter with smoky notes and nutty dry malts. 2012-09-15
Sampled at Rories house.  A gushing tan head.  A rroasted smoky aroma.  Big and bold on the first sip.  Nicely hopped.  Dark fruit.  A nice feel.  Quite nice.

Refrigerated 500 mL brown bottle poured into a snifter.  Pours black with light brown head.  Some lacing, medium body, well carbonated, and coffee/chocolate aroma.  Taste is chocolate, some dry coffee, and some herbal hops.  Good porter.

Poured from a bottle thanks to lukaduke. Pours a darker brown with a khaki colores head of foam. Aroma gas roasted oats, chocolate, light acidity, a little woody. Taste is roasty sweet. Very smooth carbonation.

Bottle.  Pour is thick and black with  large, rocky dark brown head.  Aroma is earthy with notes of wet stone, roasted malt, hay, and light coffee. Also some mineral notes.  Flavor is loaded with roasted malt, faint coffee, light cereal malt, and a clean lightly hoppy finish.  Aroma surpassed flavor on this one. Flavor was like a smooth, straight forward stout. Not quite as much subtlety and complexity as most HF beers. Still really great though.
Thanks again to Andrew for this. Brown black with a thin head. Roasted ashy aroma with some vanilla. Sweet roasted chocolate dry bakers chocolate. Good beer. Dry roast bitter finish.  7/4/8/4/15

550 ml bottle. Pours black with some red at the edges. Mocha one finger head with wonderful lacing. Aromas of coffee but mostly cocoa and some vanilla. Medium body, creamy with soft carbonation. Fantastic porter.

On tap at HF a while back.

Oh dear. This is the best American porter Ive had in recent memory. Pours a near black with a large mocha head with impressive lacing and retention. Aroma is complex and subtle, a blend of chocolate, roast malt, coffee, dark fruit, mild bitterness, and smoke. Flavor is similar, with roast and smoke providing a strong backbone for the sweet chocolate and dark fruit. Medium thick, with soft full bodied and soft carbonation. Edmund used to be my favorite American Porter. Now Everrett is.

500ml bottle courtesy of Andrew for bringing back some bottles for us... Pours smooth opaque stouty black hue with reddish auburn edges and topped with a creamy medium khaki head that slowly reduces down to a thin wispy film... Aroma of smooth roasted malt, semi-sweet chocolate and cocoa, smooth throughout with a semi-sweet grain backing. Solid and well embodies the style... Flavored follows suit with semi-sweet to sweet lightly harred roasted malt with an equally balancing level of cocoa and chocolate malt. A fair bit of grain throughout.  Smooth creamy bodied with a lighter level of carbonation. Pretty darn terrific porter with not many flaws, if any at all.

500ml bottle, shared by Dan and Tim. Thanks! Pours a deep dark brown color with a tan head and some lacing.  Aroma is roasty, malty, chocolate. Medium to heavy on the palate with soft, creamy carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, roasted malt, coffee, bittersweet chocolate, with a sweet, chocolate finish.  An excellent porter.

Trade with Xerenthar. Thanks. New Years Eve 2012. Pours black with a creamy large beige head. Really complex and tasty this is. A bit of wood, coffee, chocolate and piney hops.  Yeasty notes. Smooth , soft and very well balanced. Another lovely H.F beer.

[4916-20121102] Bottle. Roasted coffee malt and nutty wood aroma. Black body with a quick foamy brown head. Roasted nutty malt coffee flavour. Full body. Tasty if a little burnt. (8/4-/7/4/15) 3.8
(w/ blankboy, GregClow, HogTownHarry, jercraigs)
Overheard: "Magic boxes, people!"

Bottle: Poured a pitch-black color porter with a large brown foamy head with good retention and some good lacing. Aroma of dark roasted malt with light espresso notes with some light vanilla notes. Taste is a very robust porter with quite strong roasted malt notes with a side sot of espresso and light subtle green hops. Body is super full with strong carbonation, no apparent alcohol and a nice creamy texture. Probably one of the best porter I ever had a chance to drink.

I dont know how a porter can get better than this.  Pours inky black with a big effervescent dark brown head.  Aroma is bitter chocolate, coffee and dark roasted malts.  Taste is much of the same, great mouthfeel, bitter chocolate, deep roasted malts and coffee.  Very rich and very awesome.

Il y a un gros buzz autour de Hill Farmstead, ici la Everett, un porter partagé par Patrick. Merci. Liquide brun, huile à transmission, presque noir. Il y a du menthol avec du chocolat dans ce nez. La bouche est superbe, une texture grasse. Les notes de chocolats sont bien agréables et intégrées. Franchement cest bon. Pour amateur de gros porter, le buzz nest pas surfait.

Bottle, 50 cl. Opaque dark brownish black with a frothy stable beige head and a delicious aroma with notes of bread, licorice, molases, roast and light smoke. Flavor is light sweet roasted malty, high density, with a fruity orange bitter finish.

Black, very big brown head (I poured it carefully, I swear!) Smells like chocolate cake, with a cup of coffee beside it. Awesome flavor, too - chocolate cake and coffee again, but also figs, red wine, subtle oaky notes. Great stuff. Thanks to Winter 2012 Secret Santa.

Bittle at home .. thanks to BenH and Leyton (for being nice enough to trade)... dark black ... thin tan head ... soft mellow chocolate ... little creamy malts ... little fizz ... dark rich malts ... heavy malts ... dark fruit s... chocolate ...

Bottle from trade with Leighton, thanks! Pours black tight tan head. Aroma is very chocolatey, a little pine and slightly resinous, touch resinous. Taste is quite rich, ashy, chocolate, resinous pine. Palate is spot on, full bodied with a dry finish. Top gear.

Thanks Ben for this bottle. Pours a very dark brown colour with a fair, light tan head. Aroma of caramel, chocolate, oak, pine, roasty malt and alcohol. Similar flavours with mild carbonation, light CO2 prickle and an oily mouth-feel. A little pine hop character throughout. Lovely.

Bottle [500ml] shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, jerc & mabel -- c/o j&m. Nov. 2. Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with a small diminishing bubbly light-brown head. Lovely aroma of roasted malt, lots of leafy hops, a bit of vanilla, some chocolate and light lactic notes. Fantastic flavour of roasted malt, chocolate, leafy hops and a hint of alcohol. Medium bodied. An amazing Porter.

Nice black dark brown, had a nice mocha head. Aroma is coffee, nice rich dark chocolate. Maybe some well hidden dark fruits in there. Toasty, smells good. Taste: OMG this is sooo smooth and chocolaty, nice roasted coffee, creamy. This is def. the best single porter Ive had!

Michael knew how much I wanted this and generously donated it to our tasting today. Yet another extremely gracious gesture from an exceptional member of this community. Very cool. Thanks man!

The beer is dark brown, verging on black, with a gargantuan, soapy, beige head that coats the tumbler with lacing. The aroma offers chocolates, roast, malt, dark chocolates, hints of coffee. Great flavor. Really smooth. Not overpowering or exceptionally bold, but rather, well balanced, easy drinking, and highly enjoyable. One of the best porters I have ever had.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-08-2012

Bottle pour..thanks beverage warehouse for this one.. Holdout for 100th rating.. dark porter color..leaves creamy film on side of glass..aroma is quite pleasing with Chocolate..and coffee goodness..palate is very smooth and a very well done porter..Nice roastiness...one of the better porters I have ever enjoyed..thanks again evan..
UPDATED: JUN 14, 2013 A solid porter. A ncie roastiness, well-balanced, cocoa, roastiness. Very nice mouthfeel. Good all around.

Un corps presque noir et une tête crémeuse et solide.  Une langoureuse dentelle sur la paroi du verre.  Un nez complexe de chocolat et de caramel, de grains torréfiés et enfumés avec des fruits latents, de la réglisse et une tonne de houblons en feuilles, résineux et même mentholés.  Sur les papilles, lexpérience se poursuit et me coupe le souffle: les saveurs maltées sont ténébreuses et très riches tandis que les houblons sont vivifiants, cohésifs et relèvent de la pure fantasmagorie.  La sensation en bouche est pour moi parfaite.  Le corps est velouté, la texture est crémeuse et les bulles jouent le rôle de leur vie.  La finale est une démonstration de complexité et de magie noire: une amertume combinée des malts rôtis et des houblons qui reprennent leurs parfums à nen plus finir.  Bien plus quun simple porter.  Merci à tom10101 pour la bouteille.

Pours a deep umber black color with  couple fingers of mocha foam that laces out nicely. Aromas and flavors match perfectly. Nice thick creamy mouthfeel with big dark chocolate, roasted malt, touch of vanilla and coffee and a light burnt caramel finish.

Thanks, Tommy, for this one. Dark black with lovely chocolate brown frothy head and great lacing. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, slightly acidic, milk, cherries. Taste is sweet milk chocolate with a coffee undertone. Great beer.

500mL Bottle, purchased at the brewery. Saline and oceanic chocolate lusts after freshly hewn chestnut logs, visions of raw chocolate abound. On the palate, a rich and round beast, booming of hazlenut spread, fresh Parisian decaf, peppery charcoal, and warming alcohols. This is quite good dark beer. Solid, reliable, but nuanced, expressive, and of high quality. It doesnt overstep its bounds an make classic high gravity dark beer mistakes, like too much roast, too much chocolate malt, too much sugar, not enough sugar, or too much alcohol. It walks all of these lines perfectly and thats why its so damn fantastic.

2012-11-02. Black body with a nice tan head that fades. Good amount of green hops in the aroma, modest dry roast. 7++ Flavour is similar, rich dark malt core, good amount of green leafy hops, modest dry roast, bitterness and green hops that linger in the finish. 7+ Very smooth medium bodied palate. Very nice stuff, fairly well balanced yet assertively hoppy. Bottle via trade with cfrancis"Yeti Yeti Bo-Betty, Yeaaaaaaati!"
50cl, new American brew Anno 2010, thx to Secret Santa!, very complex Porter, roasted/sweet and slightly spicy/fruity, easy to drink, very balanced, cloudy, good head, top class!, yet expensive!

500ml bottle. Pours out a dark brown with lots of mocha head. Pleasant but disappointingly weak aroma of toasted grain, treacle and hops. Its only when I take a sip that I realise why this beer has such a strong reputation. The taste works in such harmony that its hard to pin down the individual flavours, but its a great evocation of dark malty goodness with the perfect volume of hops to back it up. It has the right chocolate and coffee notes but works them in rather than overplaying them. The end result is a beer unafraid to stand on its own two feet rather than showcasing the best bits of other beverages. The mouthfeel is just about as good as can be; big enough to get lost in without being difficult to swallow. Just wish the aroma was a little more forceful. Overall though a big recommendation for this one.

On tap Positive pie 2, pours black with a tight tan head and some lace. aromas of black coffee, chocolate. Taste rich dark coffee, dark chocolate, some sweetness, medium body with long black coffee finish.

From bottles, on draught, this is one beer thats always been a show in itself. No matter what I was drinking before or after, it is a rare day the one in which you drink an Everett that is not the highlight of the day. And for what its worth, dark malt flavours are certainly not among my favourite features in the broad universe of beer... So cracking up an Everett and drinking it in front of the screen, here are my impressions. A vigorous beige cap stays above the close to blackness. Ashes blend lovingly around fudge in this complex malt nose where all kinds of chocolatey nuances dominate the caramel found in many a porter. Toasted pumpernickel, cigar leafy/smokiness, leather.. the flavours are broad, varied, complementary, never heading too much toward sweetness nor toward bitterness. Hops are not subtle, but are kept under control by the sheer malt presence. Round, luscious palate, never feeling heavy and certainly not syrupy, but straightly dense and compact, stealing a vanilla kiss toward the finish, but otherwise remaining disciplined, adding woodsy, truffle, coffee laden layers and inspiring the drinker to expand its dark malt aroma descriptors range. The texture is simply flawless, with just the right carbonation dosage, soft bubbles enhancing drinkability while never bringing forth more acidity and bite than required, leaving the rich maltiness the grounding area it needs to land its intricacies on the palate. Tough to imagine anything I would change.

Bottle shared amongst friends. This has to be one of the best porters Ive had in recent memory, disregarding the Funky Buddha stuff of course. The coffee chocolate flavors are just super intense and only got better as it warmed up. Outstanding!

Bottle (50 cl), courtesy of _angst_. Black with beige head. Intense dark chocolate aroma, with some salmiak and gunpowder in the background. Medium bodied, medium carbonation. Semi dry, medium bitterness. My first sample from this brewery, a good start.

Huge thanks to Eric (Holland) for giving me this as an extra(!!). 500 ml bottle served in a CBS snifter.

A: Pours a solid black color with a brown head forming on the pour. It recedes to a thin cap and collar that leaves some nice sticky, soapy lace down the glass.

S: Roasted malts and coffee beans up front. Some light bakers chocolate and some toffee.

T: The taste is transcendent. Milk chocolate, nice roasted malts and some chocolate covered espresso beans all fill my mouth and run across my taste buds. Delicious vanilla sweetness with a light toffee richness to it. The finish is a little bitter bakers chocolate, a hint of burnt sugar and some light molasses as well.

M: Creamy mouthfeel with a medium body. Medium low carbonation with a nice combination of roast and sweet notes on the finish with just a hint of dryness. The drinkability is off the charts.

O: This is an incredibly decadent treat. Rich and creamy with great notes of roast, chocolate and espresso. This is the best porter money can buy. I will be seeking this out again, and very soon.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-02-2012

500 ml bottle received in trade. Thank you Glouglouburp! Pours very dark brown, almost black, with a small frothy dark mocha head that slowly dissipates while leaving some thin lacing on the glass. Smell is slightly sweet and malty with roasted malts, quality chocolate, dark roar coffee, pumpernickel, roasted nuts and hints of cereal.Taste is tiny sweet, bitter and malty with roasted malts, cocoa powder, slightly sweet dark bread, moist grass, wood, roasted nuts, vanilla and hints of citrus. Mouthfeel is soft, creamy, round and medium bodied. Finish is timy sweet, slightly bitter and malty with roasted malts, pumpernickel, dark roast coffee, moist grass, liquorice root and slightly peppery wood. Great balanced stuff as usual.

Bottle at USA comes to Skövde. Black beer with a nice brown head. Aroma from licorice and cocoa powder, spicy, chilli notes, dark chocolate, bitter hops, roasted, tar, vanilla, milk chocolate, woody, smoked, peat notes. Dark chocolate flavor, vanilla, tar, licorice, hay, peat, spicy, cocoa powder, roasted, woody, coffee bean, milk chocolate, vanilla, some hay and grass. Wonderful mouthfeel and with a well balanced roasted finish with cocoa powder, chocolate, chilli wood and tar.

Bottle rlgks tasting. Pours black with a nice bubbly tanned head leaving small laces. Aroma is coffee chocolate roasted malts sweet fruity appleas and pears. Flavor is velvety fullbodied heavy dark chocolate coffee roasted malty yet not harsh just heavy overwhelming, beautiful sweetness and bitterness just spot on. Finishes with a pleasant roasted malty bitter and slightly sweet aftertaste.

Sampled at USSkovde
Black with a beige head. 
Sourish and spicy aroma; milky chocolate, and some peat. 
Milky chocolate in the flavour as well. Some tar and peat.
Pretty high bitterness and a bit harsh.
Roasted with a soft and smooth mouthfeel.

Sampled at UCTS testing. Pours pitch black with a small brown head. Smells coffee, abit chocolate and roasted malt. Tastes coffee and roasted malt, abit watery then a clear raisins roasted malt finish.

Courtesy of BOLTZ7555!!! Thanks Jason. It pours dark murky mahogany body that supports a thin tan head of foam. The aroma offers up dark roasted malts, some brownie, malt balls, some black licorice and a mild cedar wood like spiciness. The taste is rich with a mix of dark roasted malts, molasses and rolling into yummy sticky chocolate brownie. It gets a bit spicy like it has been aged on cedar or thats just sort of a spicy black licorice sensation. Dandy stuff.

Bottle pour by iadler. Pours dark oily brown with a nice soapy khaki tan head that settles to a wispy film an sudsy collar. Aroma has a sweet smokiness of malt subtle anise and chocolate. Taste is sweet roasted smokey malt and coco along with a decent bitterness. Palate is full chalky an dry. What can I say the hype lives on, its lovely!
Bottle shared by Iadler!  Dark black pour, little lacing and dark chocolate aroma.  Flavor is also bitter dark chocolate, sweet caramel and smoky peat on the aftertaste.  Really damn nice.
UPDATED: DEC 29, 2013 Bottle. Very dark thick pour with a beige head. Huge aroma and taste of chocolate, coffee, licorice, and some smoke. Phenomenal.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2013 On tap at the beer store.  Pours black.  Aroma of lots of roasted malts, coffee and dark chocolate, and some floral hops.  Flavor very strong, and a little smoky.  Smooth to thicker texture.  A really good beer.
EDIT: Poured from a growler.  Still black with a lacy, beige head.  So much from the dark, roasted malts.  A great porter.

Poured a thick oily glass into a smokestack glass. Aroma is coffee, chocolate and smoke. Taste is very well balanced mixture of milk chocolate, dark chocolate, molasses, toffee and booze. This bottle is still a bit hot bit it's very drinkable. Finishes pretty dry. Great beer!

Bottle shared by drewbeerme. Pours a deep brown-black with a dark tan head. The nose is fantastic. Cocoa and toasty malt. Faint herbal hops play in the back ground. Rich and inviting. On tasting, there is a nice medium body, almost creamy. No astringency. Chocolate and roast, balanced bitterness overall. Light sweet note. Superb porter, for sure.

Not overly aggressive...just incredibly balanced.  The flavor profile, aroma, and creaminess are a perfectly orchestrated symphony.  Cocoa, dark-roasted coffee, gooey caramel and mouthwatering toffee, along with decadent fudge, brownie batter, and molasses are evident.  Do believe Ive experienced better in the style (Olfabrikken Porter, Funky Buddha MBC Porter, Dark Knight Returns) although this is one of the most traditional.  Could drink this stuff all day...if readily available.  Damn!

Pours stout-like black color with minimal head.  Aroma of chocolate, dark fruit, and coffee.  Chocolate and coffee flavor with some dark fruit sweetness and hint of smoke.  One of the best Ive had in a while.

500ml bottle from Winooski Beverage Warehouse purchased last May (thanks guys!) poured into stem glass.  OK wait.  WOW.  Pours one of the deepest and most opaque black Ive ever seen.  Taking a LED flashlight through the glass, you cant see a thing!!  Head is practically nonexistent, only a small ring prevails.  Aroma is, oh gosh, a symphony of cocoa, dark chocolate, dried fruits, tobacco, slight vanilla, coffee, caramel malt, very faint alcohol, and a nice blend of hops in the background, wow, seriously I understand why the guy at Winooski just dumped this in my hands when I asked him to show me around and mentionned that stouts and porters were one of my favs...!!!  They had just received a case and it was almost gone 20mins later...Ok back on track!  Taste is medium-sweet, bitterness is floating in the background.  This is REALLY well-balanced; the only other American robust porter I had was Smuttynoses and although I liked that one really really much for its sugar contents and milk-chocolate like qualities, I like the Everett a bit more for its balance and more "mature" characteristics.  If it was possible, Id give it 4.65 as I gave Smuttynoses 4.6.  Palate is also out of this world, so slick and smooth...with a soft carbonation which slightly tingles your tongue.  Finish is long, roasty (pretty rare, normally it degrades into acidity) and a just a bit bitter.  Overall, you know what?  I just fell off my chair, and no, Im not drunk.  This is a beer to be treated with respect, a masterpiece.  I waited from May until the early days of autumn to drink this as I had a feeling it would be a great, comforting drink to accompany a chilly night and although this might be getting a bit too poetic, well, I was right.  Bravo.

Guest tap earlier this summer at Cigar City. Aroma was typical of a great porter, smokey, cocoa hints of coffee. First sip caused me to check to confirm that this was, indeed, a porter. This richness and mouth feel was better than many imperial stouts! This was the best porter that Ive had the pleasure of enjoying!

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2014 Draft at Eulogy. Opaque brown with a thick brown foamy head. Huge porter. Chocolate caramel. Somewhat smoky. Sweet charcoal. Burnt marshmallow. Espresso. Tootsie Rolls. Smoked bacon. Black as pitch but still quite creamy. Probably the best Hills Farmstead has to offer. Which is meant as a compliment.

Opaque dark chocolate bar color, gorgeous tan head via pour from very fresh bottle acquired in trade. Huge chocolate and cacao nose, grassy/straw hop aromas, too.  Hits the lips with blast of sweetness and immediate complexity.  Robust is the perfect adjective, bursting with flavor, rich, thick but not overly heavy.  Toasty malts are absolutely perfect with the middle of the mouthful feeling creamy and desert-like. The hops provide a very distinct grapefruit aroma as it warmed and some citrus notes lingered with the grassiness at the very finish.  An amazing porter, easily the best Ive had in a bottle.  Dying to try more from this brewery!!

On mavait vanté le charisme dEverett dès mon arrivé chez Hill Farmstead. Après plusieurs dégustations aussi pugnaces les unes des autres, Everett  réussi a briller. Les sucres proviennent de partout et font tout, le corps est riche mais digeste et les houblons fonctionnent en symbiose avec la balance des saveurs. Noix de coco, tabac, chocolat, caramel, figues, nougat et une liste de végétaux résineux et aromatiques. En fût comme en bouteille,  un chef doeuvre.

Wow.  This is freaking good.  Reminds me a lot of Founders Porter.  Some citrus hops and an amazing roast malt depth.  This makes me want to go buy a sixes of Founders right now! Fantastic balance of roast and pine and citrus.

22 oz bomber into a tulip glass. No clue what age/vintage it is, but I believe its somewhat fresh.

A - Pitch black body which lets zero light through. Massive fluffy mocha head. Settles down to a frothy cap with crazy amounts of retention. The foam just clings to the glass the entire time. Probably the best lacing Ive ever seen on a beer.

S - Robust indeed. Deep roasty malts, fresh espresso beans, sweet and lactic milk chocolate, and a touch of bitter mineral rich water. Finishes with sweet and rich vanilla. Perfect aroma.

T - Follows the nose with a pleasant mix of intense espresso beans, milk chocolate, vanilla and perfectly roasted malts. Just a touch of hop bitterness to work against the sweetness and richness of it all. Booze isnt present in the taste but there is a light warmth happening in the throat. 

M - Slick and coating mouth feel. Very silky with a high level of carbonation that prevents it from being cloying. 

O - The best porter Iv ever had, easily. Which sucks considering how tough it is to get bottles of this beer. Hype and availability aside, Hill Farmstead is the real deal. Unbelievable beer.

Bottle pours black tan head. Very smooth creamy has a bit of carb in it. Tastes smells roasty chocolate bit of Vinillia. Has a nice crisp finish. Everyone says not too bit I felt it was just before it mellowed out. Over all mi e beer.

Black with medium dark brown head.  Aroma is all roast.  Taste is smooth, roasty, none of the tartness that ruins most porters for me.  Body is smooth with medium to light crisp carbonation.  This is the best porter I have ever had.
Draft at railroad. Pours pitch black with no head to speak of. Aroma is chocolate and coffee and very sweet. Taste is chocolate up front with a sharp coffee ground finish.

Pours pitch black with a creamy medium mocha head...looks thick.  Aroma has very nice roastiness with mild notes of espresso and dark fruit...some dark chocolate.  Flavor follows suit...very rich and roasty...not much burnt but nice espresso, chocolate, and dark fruit...not muddled at all!  Mouthfeel is medium/full and creamy with a bold roasty finish that has nice bitterness.  Fabulous!

A seemingly massive, robust, and sophisticated take on this style that almost totally takes off.  Giant and deep aroma of purplish fruit, chocolate and coffee, heavy on roast and caramelized sugars.  Flavor is similar but packed with a bit more forthright sweetness, especially heavy on a frustratingly thin vanilla note.  Medium palate; given the indicators, it ought to be heavier.  Finishes with heavy licorice and a somewhat long semi-sweet smack of maple and wood; close to an excellent example.

22 oz. from the Booyamachine himself. There was a lot of hype surrounding this beer when it was bestowed upon me. Usually that would be the death knell for any brew but this one did not disappoint. "Robust" doesnt even begin to describe how ballsy this beer is. Huge roast and an interesting hop profile make the finish pretty bitter. Makes for a deep an thought-provoking beer. My only qualm is that mine smelled funny. The coffee aromas are fighting with some kind of vegetal/sour smell. I think I poured it in a dirty glass, which is a shame. Now Ill never complete my BJCP.

Pours a pitch black rich looking beer with a darker tab head. The aroma is full of chocolate, caramel and a hint of roasted coffee. This is a very rich beer that still allows for a hint of earth hops to come through. Great full body, amazing taste...this might be the perfect American Porter. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2013 Acquired through trade, courtesy of Adam. Thanks Man!  Bottle shared at Home with friends. Poured pitch black with a small tan head and good lacing. Very viscous and syrup-like in appearance. Smell is dark chocolate, light char, dark fruit, coffee, a touch of leather, vanilla, graham crackers, and light tobacco. Taste is very chocolatey, tobacco, licorice, dark fruits, espresso, toasted malt, earthy, chewy, and char. Getting a lot of coffee lingering in the finish and it is delicious. Seriously creamy mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Very nice beer and easily the best porter I have ever had. A dark, malty, roasty porter with an assertively balanced hop presence; something I could drink everyday of the week. Every time I drink this thing I love it more and more. Could possibly be my favorite beer of all-time. Simply exceptional.
last bottle of the day, well- besides the summer pils?? .. . pours a depp black brown .. good foam .. . deep tar and charcoal .. . a very nice porter .. . . i really hope he grows out of this..

Bottle shared at RBSG Grand Tasting, 2012. Nice black with lace. Nose is a typically roasted porter nose, not that impressive. Flavor is sweet, milky, creamy chocolate, a little bit of tang. Amazingly soft body. It must be the water that gives this wonderful softness

500ml bottle into point glass. Black with thick creamy chocolate milk committed head.nose of coca and light hops. Not as heavy as expected from the look, light in the mouth with a hint of hops and long village aftertaste.Nice, but I want it to be a little more complexity up front. Just not getting the smoke and dark fruit others seem to pick up on

Bottle direct from HF. Used a English pint glass. Thick, beige head that slowly diminished after about half the glass. Nose and taste are deep and seductive. Aromas of coffee, notes of tobacco, small hint of chocolate.  Thick, velvety mouthfeel. Medium body leaning on the full side. Flavor has lots of dry roasted malt, chocolate and a bit of ash. After a few more sips, it shows another level of complexity. Licorice, a bit of dark fruit and bitterness from a high end espresso bean. 7.5% is not noticeable at all.  Is this a high end stout or a porter?? Absolutely rich and decadent.  I drink a lot of porters and love the style, this brew is exceptional in every way.

pours beautifully. smells of chocolate, prunes, coffee roastery. this is everything i want in a porter. hints of smoke, dark chocolate, dried fruit, coffee....but i emphasize hints because all the flavors work so well together and nothing lingers. "feels delightfully creamy in my mouth" is what Lushawn said to Phaleslu about something else one time. i think the same can be said to the fullest extent about this delicious treat. Now i just wish it were more readily available in the boston area....

This is the best Porter I have ever had. Smooth, rich without being heavy, sweet but not cloyingly so. One of my favorite beers.caramel, coffee, roasty, chocolate, dough, black, brown foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, full body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish,

Served on-tap at Teresas Next Door during Philly Beer Week.

A - Pours deep brown, might as well be black, with a nice one and a half finger tall mocha colored head leaving thin trails of lace down parts of the glass.

S - Smells of chocolate, coffee, molasses, licorice and plenty of dark roasted malts. A bit of smoke comes through as it sits in the glass. Very nice nose.

T - Starts off with a ton of sweet dark roasted flavors - namely coffee, chocolate and molasses - slowly giving way to some of the other flavors - licorice, smoke and a bit of dark fruit. The dark roasted malt is ever present. Finish is quite roasty but the smooth feel really helps to keep things in check.

M - Big, smooth body with a ton of dark flavors and moderate carbonation. Nice creamy feel brings everything together.

O - I could drink this beer every day no problem. It possesses all of the flavors I look for in a dark beer and the execution is nearly flawless. This deserves all of the praise it receives.

500ml bottle shared by atom.  Pours a dark black with a frothy, brown head.  Woah, what a wonderful aroma.  Smells like a bag of coffee beans with chocolate, roasted malt and a hop backbone.  Full bodied for a porter, this is perfectly balanced between notes of dark chocolate truffle, roasted malt, coffee, and some earthy hop overtones.  Really smooth and drinkable.  If I had access to this on a regular basis, it would be definite go to porter.  Its a pretty fucking awesome porter.

Bottle shared by atom.  My first thoughts when looking at this beer is that it is much darker than that Pipeworks imperial porter.  This also has a great looking tan head.  Rich coffee and chocolate aroma.  Its so simple, but it is so great.  Creamy texture, with a big roast coffee character.  Flavor also has dark chocolate with a nice bitter finish, but it also has a nice blackberry component to it.  It is simple, to me, but I think this is incredible.

Bottle thanks to SS, pours dark brown/ black with a medium deep tan head. Aroma hits some nice senses in me head, chocolate, coffee, hops, molasses, dark malts, and pretzel bread. Could ask for a better balance in this aroma. So smooth, chocolate and coffee intertwined perfect, with slight roasted malt, molasses, hops, and yeast bringing it altogether. Damn near perfect,  easy drinking, extremely well balanced. I could drink this all day everyday, lovely!

Review from notes taken at Cigar City Brewing taproom on 7/15/12. Poured on draft into a Cigar City shaker pint glass.

Appearance: Pours a dark brown, almost black with a 1/2 finger light tan head. Decent lacing.

Smell: Roasted coffee, chocolate, toasted malt and white bread crust.

Taste: Milk chocolate, roasted malt and coffee throughout. Aftertaste is bitter coffee with a touch of sweet chocolate. Extremely well-balanced. Excellent flavor.

Mouthfeel: Medium-to-full-bodied with a decent amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: Excellent drinkability. I could drink this all day.

Overall: Excellent beer overall. Maybe the best porter (its really close to a milk stout in my opinion) Ive ever had. Its extremely well-balanced and smooth. Id recommend trying this one if you get a chance. I hope Im lucky enough to get some bottles of Everett at some point.

My first from HF. Very excited for this one! Poured into a Highland pint glass. 

Pours a deep foreboding black. Heavy and scary looking. A great finger width of luscious mocha-head rests atop. The nose is rich with roasted malt, coffee grounds, dark breads, molasses. Well-rounded aroma invites me to partake. 

For the style, the feel holds up wonderfully. Velvety chewy mouth with a moderately-full heft to it. This is not an easy drinker, and thats fine by me. Holds up the decadence of the flavors perfectly. The beer is overflowing with rich, malty goodness. Roasted coffee stands out, followed by a not-unpleasant burst of charred bread. Semi-sweet chocolate, cut oats on the finish. Fantastic Porter. One of the best. Id love to have this one again.

Having a glass at Cigar City as a guest tap. Pours and laces just like a fine RIS. Aroma is light espresso , roasted malts and slightly smoky. Taste is much like aroma and smooth. Very easy to drink, and you taste the craftmanship. Excellent porter indeed. Thanks To all involved who made it possible to enjoy this.

Bottle at home Stockholm, Sweden. This beer blew my mind. Didnt find any flaws at all. Dont think the perfect beer exists but this is damn close to the perfekt Imp porter. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle many thanks to Bruce at his Housewarming Tasting. It pours jet black, with a medium light tan head. The nose is roasted malt, caramel, coffee, cocoa, rich roast and chocolate milk. The taste is chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, charcoal, touch of spice, caramel and bitterness in the finish. Medium-full body, moderate carbonation and foamy mouth-feel. Smooth and very well balanced. Straight-up delicious!

Ive had this beer on a few occasions but this is the first time reviewing it. Picked this up at the brewery on Saturday. Enjoyed at Cellar Temp (60 Degrees F) in a HIll Farmstead Glass on a warm summer afternoon.

A - Poured a dark brown to black out of the bottle. Appearance post-pour is pitch black with brown bits along the edge of the glass. Head of 1-finger brown like coffee that sticks around for a very long time fading slowly. 

S - Very dry roasted malts, hint of bakers chocolate orange citrus and liquorice. Some coffee and tobacco. 

T - Wow. Up front, this very burnt dark malts taste of liquorice and smoke. Smoked malts for sure in this on and a touch of vanilla. Coffee and Chocolate follow with the finish of roasted espresso beans. Theres this very light and almost floral texture at the finish that makes you thirsty to take another drink. 

M - 40% carbonation on the mouth swish. Medium body with a light candy like finish.

O - This beer comes in growler filles (750ML / 2L) and 500ML bottles. Its hard to imagine sharing anything less than 750ML with a friend. This beer is the most delicious and drinkable porter Ive ever had. I dont drink too many of them because they tend to be very bitter at the finish, mouth drying or too boring on the palate. This beer looks, smells, tastes and finishes perfectly and the 7.5% ABV is not noticeable at all despite any cheapening effects such as vanilla or oak chips. Theres a reason this is #1 in the Porter Style on RateBeer.

Bottle @ Bruces Housewarming Tasting. Deep brown with a massive tan head. Plenty of floating yeast globules. The nose is deep toasty brown pumpernickel bread, some nutella, roasted nuts and dark chocolate. Vinous, slightly woody. The taste is full, toasty chocolate syrup, burnt brown bread and rich raspberry. Nutty, full, lightly dry on the long finish. Thick and rich. Overall, pretty great.

Pours jet black with a mocha head. Aroma of smokey chocolate. Taste follows, thick and chocolatey, smoke is there but not too much. Really amazing!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

50cl bottle pours a hazy brown with some clumpy, wispy, tan head.  Nose is coffee, brown sugar, nutty, bread, malty.  Flavor is sweet, brown sugar, bread, coffee grounds, malty, a little vanilla.  Medium bodied, sweet finish.
Bottle to snifter (thanks alexsdad06). Looks good; dark brown with thin lacing. Smells pretty good; malty and nutty. Tastes good; rich with a nice mouthfeel. The best American Porter Ive ever had.

Bottle poured a magnificent dark espresso with a huge khaki head and notable lacing.  Welcoming aroma of milk chocolate, coffee, oatmeal, and roasted malts.  First sip is just as good as the aroma beginning with oats, malts, and hint of dark fruit leading to palatable blend of coffee and hop bitterness and very smooth finish.  Enjoyable mouthfeel and slight roasty, smokey flavors linger on the palate.  Complex yet extremely drinkable porter.
Porter? Its darker than some stouts.  Dark roasted chocolate aromas. Dark chocolate and coffee flavors. An awesome porter!

Bottled. Pours a dark brown color with a thin tan head. Decent head retention. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, vanilla and toasted malts. The taste is roasted malts, chocolate, vanilla, bitter citrus hops. Medium bodied.

On tap during Philly beer week- pours blackish with a tannish offwhite head. aroma takes your breath away, chocolate, coffee, malt, beckoning a sip. Sip is as good as aroma. Big malty flavors wash over the pallet, with overtones of chocolate coffee espresso everything a porter should be. I dont know how many times I said this is the best porter I had when I was drinking this. It was more than once.

bottle shared by Mike, Wow. this was one good porter, easily as good as olfabrikken (from memory), just awesome flavor, really balanced easily drinkable, a little light in the body but for a porter it was definitely a porter not trying to be too much.. awesome.
Wow. Didnt know Porter could taste this good--its up there with any Imperial Stout Ive tried. From a 750ml bottle fresh from the brewery.

Bottle from David - thanks!  Black pour with a froth of expresso tan foam.  Aroma is bone dry roast with oats, silky chocolate, light hop bitterness on the back third, and dark fruit notes into the finish.  Taste is oat, roast, soft and bitter chocolate, coffee bitterness, hop bitterness, and distinct raisin and plum (or perhaps simply the darker malt showing) through the finish with some lingering hop bitterness.  Mouthfeel is smooth and clean.  Masterpiece of a porter.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 Deep black brown body, moderate sized dirty-white head.  Spotty lacing.  Nose is complex with hints of caramel chocolate roast and molasses.  Flavor is similar in construction to the nose with sweeter malts dominate without being cloying.  Roasted characteristics are the highlight.  Mouthfeel is spot on.  Medium bodied, silky, mellow carbonation, light sweetness, with a hint of a twang.  Simply divine.  I think this displaces Taddy Porter as my favorite porter on the block.  Well done.
Aroma of.roasty coffee, nuts, and chocolate.  Pours black with little film.  Taste is chocolate, sweet ccoffee and caramel.  Sooo delicious.

Shared with my wife who is just now sneaking sips of beer after her pregnancy. At the time of this review, this is the #2 American Porter on the top style list and this beer is also on the Top Beers - Popular list at spot #70.

Beer is black / dark brown and hazy with a nice off white head of small tan bubbles, lacing, nice carbonation...

Aroma is mildly roasty, mildly alcohol, smells like a porter should, mildly sweet.

Beer is medium to light in body, pretty sweet on the lead off but the back palate is all porter all the time. Great little beer, wonderful how the alcohol is there without the beer being boozy, sweet, strong, drinkable...nice.
500 ml thanks to Matt. Big chocolate pour. Total roast flavor and aroma. Nice burnt aroma as well on nose. Simply delicious.

Bottle from joeybones3.  Full disclosure, a little of this bottle had leaked in transit so I drank it right away.  A light hiss when cracking the cap.  Very tasty stuff; lots of mocha flavor, perhaps tilting toward straight out chocolate, along with notes of licorice, sweet molasses, ash, and roasty bitterness in the finish.  Full-bodied, robust indeed, yet silky smooth and creamy in the body.  One of the better Porters Ive had and a trip to Vermont this summer will allow me to give it another go.

Bottle 500ml.
Pours black with brown creamy head. Sick lacing. Aroma is of roasted malt, coffee, alchool. Taste is of roasted malt, coffee, bitterness, warming alchool, chocolate. Full bodied, nice mouthfeel. Very robust.

Bottle. Pours a black color with a tan head. Aroma is nice and roasty with coffee, dark chocolate, burnt notes, dark fruits, subtle vanilla and sugary notes. The flavor follows the nose with lots of dark chocolate and sweet sugar and some vanilla notes, I get some dark fruits, coffee, roasted malt, burnt notes and liquorice. The body is the bigger side of full with a creamy mouth feel. Overall a really tasty and robust Porter, one of the better Porters I have had.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2014 Pours black with a brown head. Aroma of dark dried fruits, sweet liquorice. earthy porter roastyness, chocolate, mellow caramel and coffee. Taste of dark dried fruits, roasted malts, coffee, some hops, earthy porterish spice, liquorice and overall a classy and delicious porter. Not "Extreme" in any way but I could drink this all the time. Very pleasing!

Bottle 500 ml. Pours black with a medium brown head and a nice lacing. Aroma is good, though maybe too subtle: roasted malt, coffee, alcohol and a bit of porto. Taste is the same as aroma, but much more discernible, with some chocolate also. Very complex and well balanced. Not far from a 10 out 10. Palate is good, nice warming alcohol, creamy texture. Dry finish. Overall, an outstanding robust porter!
Bouteille 500 ml. Robe noire, collet brun moyen et beau lacing. Excellent arôme, quoiquun peu subtil: malt rôti, café, alcool et porto. Le goût est semblable à larôme, mais en plus explosif, avec une touche de chocolat en plus. Complexe et bien balancé. Pas loin dun 10/10. Texture crémeuse, finale sèche. Une excellente Robust Porter

Bottle 500 ml. Pours black with a medium creamy brown head. Super lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Slight porto notes. Taste of coffee, roasted malt, caramel and chocolate. Slight bitterness. Palate is creamy but ends dry. Warming alcohol. Surprisingly robust for a porter. Very complex and nice balance. A masterpiece!

0.5l bottle from Ølbutikken. My first Hill Farmsted and what a number 1 this is! It pours a amazing looking pitch black body with a massive and ever lasting almost fluffy espresso head thats really lacing down the whole glass. Looks amazing in my Mikkeller glass.. On the aroma this is lovely roasted and hoppy, lots of subtle small chocolate - cocoa tones dancing in the background with hints of both ashes, wood, rocks and some really subtle vanilla and leather all the way in the back. Amazing! The flavor is just soo silky and smooth! Strong and roasted - more than the aroma would suggest, lots of dry espresso and cocoa powder, ashy - almost smoky tones and its just perfectly hopped. Feels like drinking carbonated velvet. Lingering aftertaste with coffee, chocolate, hints of lingonberries and dont forget the lovely roasted malts. Really really tasty! 04.05.2012

(Rating #7500) Bottle This beer rocks! Pitch black ale with a small, creamy, khaki head. The bouquet offers cocoa intertwined with notes of pecan, maple, dry, hearty red wine and a subtle earthy component. Full-bodied and creamy with tingly carbonation. The flavor is of plush, semi-sweet, chocolate cake batter with a carbonic, bitter finish. Big-time thanks go out to landhoney for sharing this bottle of liquid luxury!

Bottle. It pours very dark brown with a nice tan head that settles to a thick half inch layer. The aroma is at first piney with hints of citrus hoppiness backed by a roasty toasty malt character. Some dark chocolate and nuts. The flavor is the same. Very velvety mouthfeel with potent earthy piney hops and rich dark malts. The roasted malt takes center stage in the finish with some coffee and tobacco smoke, supported nicely by piney hops again. Full bodied and very enjoyable.

Bottle via a trade. Pours with a pitch black hue (no light can escape) with a massive, deep khaki brown head that lasts and leaves good lace. Aromas are very nice, roasty, deep chocolate, tobacco, vinous, deep coffee notes, dark fruits, light currant and a light hoppy character. Flavors are coffee, rich and deep, mocha, mild dark fruits, very nice, complex and rounded chocolate notes, a bready malt character. Very long duration, rich malt and lots of coffee. Full bodied, medium rich. Medium carbonation, no signs of alcohol. Very impressive.


An incredibly complex and tasty beer. I cannot imagine a better porter at that abv. Absolutely nailed it.
Compliments of Jale at the pre-DLD Flossmoor party. This was my first Hill Farmstead brew and Im happy to say they are not over-hyped. Outstanding porter; well done fellas.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2012 Pour out of 22 oz bottle, hazy black pour with nice creamy tan head, looks great.  Aroma has notes of nice smoke, slight bacony notes, hints of caramel, toffee, dark chocolate notes, hints of roast, slight dark fruits with raisin and plum.  This smells great.  Taste is nice and creamy, dark fruits, chocolate, dark cocoa powder, hints of smoke, coffee, touch of molasses, finishing fairly bitter and drying.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2012 Bottle @ Armins house. Thanks Dany! Black appearance with a bubbly, light brown head. Fairly roasty, a bit smoky, dark chocolate, light caramel, espresso aroma. Creamy, roasty dark chocolate malty, cocoa, light vanilla, a touch burnt flavor. Creamy mouth feel. A slightly bitter finish but a nice overall beer. This is one of those rare beers that I wasnt overly impressed by the aroma but was quite impressed by the taste. Update: aroma is awesome!

500 ml bottle via Lubiere, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 
App.:  Deep brown-black with a decent mocha head.
  
Aroma:  Rich chocolate, tangy, black coffee notes, a touch smoky, some molasses and black licorice, maybe some grape-like fruitiness, rich, nice for a Porter.
  
Palate:  Medium-full body, soft effervescence, silky.
  
Flav.:  Rich dark chocolate with some coffee notes, less tangy than the nose, still a little fruity, molasses, a wee touch smoky, nice; dry with decent bitterness and a long, inky, molasses and dark chocolate finish.

Not a huge Porter fan.  This is certainly nice though.

750ml growler picked up from the brewery yesterday. Pours a black body with an inch thick, dense and creamy, dark brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a gorgeous lacing throughout. Aroma is awesome with rich dark chocolates, piney hops, and roasts giving off some tobacco. Some citrus to the resiny pines, a touch of coffee, and a hint of nutty toffee behind the roasts and hops. Flavor is just as impressive with rich dark chocolates, slightly chewy toffees, and plenty of roasts and hops. Resiny pines with some citruses, a light tobacco, some wood, a touch of coffee, and a hint of nuts and raisins. Resiny hops, roasts, tobacco-wood, and a touch of licorice grows into the end as this finishes dry, but ultra soft and smooth with a very rich dark chocolate and touch of chewy maltiness alongside a medium bitterness. Lengthy aftertaste following a decadent, silky smooth, medium body and a super soft, moderate carbonation. Overall, Ive tried some amazing beers from Hill Farmstead over the past few days, but this is by far the most impressive. An absolutely brilliant porter. Tons of decadent chocolates and a hint of slightly chewy toffee with plenty of resiny, piney hops giving off a light citrus and a full, balanced, hard roastiness giving off a touch of tobacco and coffee. Such a wonderful palate on this beer as well. Wow.

750 ml swingtop growler shared by bsuedekum- thanks again, Blake! Pours a dark coffee brown with a dark tan head. Rich, roasty aroma, with toastyed malts, chocolate, tobacco, wood, nuts, and beef jerky. The flavor follows the same lines- so rich and roasty, toasty, nutty, earthy, woody, and ashy. Medium-bodied, with low carbonation and a smooth, rich, robust mouthfeel. Man, oh man, this is good. Excellent porter that teeters on the edge of being a strong/imperial porter.

Bottle courtesy of Bonke. Malts, chocolate, bread, toffee, light hops, slight coffee, finishes with pine. Complexity, particularly evident in balance. Body is full, mouthfeel oily, carbonation medium. Cannot stress the exquisite balance enough, it truly makes the beer.
Bottle thanks Ernesto!!  Pours black with amazing head. Aroma of nuts toffee chocolate amazing. Taste is super roasted chocolate goodness best porter Ive had so far

Bottle. Aroma has notes of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, citrus hops and toast.  Very nice nose.  Pitch black with an average light tan frothy head that really wanted to stick around and left good lace.  Flavor is medium sweet and medium/heavy bitter.  Palate is full bodied and oily soft with a medium finish.  Overall a real surprise.  Easily the one of, if not the, best porter that Ive had.  Great roasted nose with noticeable hops, gorgeous looking beer, balanced taste and a rich full body.  Fantastic beer!  Loved it.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Pours completely black with a big, staying, creamy, beige head. Lovely lacings. Aroma has maple syrup, coffee, dark chocolate, mild astringency, roasted malts, kinda oaky. Medium carbonation, great creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is elegant, soft astringency, good coffee, again some maple syrup sweetness, liqourice, lots of dark chocolate adding lots of malty bitterness. Exquisite balance.

A deep dark porter with a thin lacing dark brown head. In aroma, a pleasant complex chocolate with herbal licorice, coffee grinds, light Brett. In mouth, a wonderful bitter chocolate with mocha coffee, lingering British hops, molasses, herbal, beautiful. On tap at the brewery, March 12, 2012.

At capones, poured a black color with small coffee head. Notes were sour, saison pepper and lemon, rich chocolate, spice, roasted malt, annis, espresso, and mocha jahva. Body is amazing, creamy and smooth. They dont make many bad beers I reckon.

On tap, poured a dark black color with aromas of roast, chocolate, hint of licorice, and some hoppy citrus notes.  Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, cocoa, light licorice, and some citrus from the hops.  Blended nicely, overall a great beer that I wish I could drink every day.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2013 On draft at the Pony Bar, already rowdy at 6:15, with a nitwit shouting abuse at me as I tried to enjoy it.  Also had some at Denises party, which resulted in an upgrade.  So this is now the #1 porter - wow.   Dark chocolate, imported coffee, woodsmoke, molasses, and herbs in the flavor.  Very interesting.

From notes.  First reviewed 1/22/2012.  Poured from a 500 mL bottle into a snifter.

With a fairly aggressive pour, there is a nice, tightly wound mocha brown cap. The head retains nicely and leaves some nice spotty lace all over the glass.

The aroma and flavor are both very smooth. Dark roasted malt contains dark semi-sweet chocolate and creamy espresso flavor with no smokey or burnt character. 

The flavor starts with that malt, and the malt and chocolate linger through the middle of the flavor, ending with a semi-sweet creamy espresso note. There is a soft spicy pine hop note right at the end. 

The mouthfeel is worth noting separately. The flavors integrate well with the smooth body and creamy carbonation.

I havent been blown away with the Hill Farmstead beers I have had so far, but this was very impressive. At this point I would say it is one of the best porters I have had.
