My first beer from this hyped brewery. Dark opaque color, small steady brown head. Chocolaty, dry roasted aroma. Full-bodied. Very roasted, some tobacco. Light bitterness in the finish. Very robust.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2013 Wow - I think it is the best porter hands down. The beer pours dark coffee unclear in color with a huge creamy caramel head on top, just about perfect. The aroma bring sweet roasted malt and coffee notes delicious in the nose. The flavor of roasted malts and bitter but smooth subtle coffee settle well on the palate. The body is the best part, so creamy and as big as an imperial porter, it puts it over the edge for sure.
Rich Roasty aroma with notes of coffee. Big bold mouthfeel  bitter licrorice chocolate and coffee. This is a complex beer that is very drinkable. Amazing
Growler shared by sajaad. Black cola pour no head. Coffee and chocolate roast aroma. Taste is super roast and chocolate upfront and then the taste fades a bit. Great damn porter. Very robust.
Growler pour, lots of chocolate in the aroma, the taste is very coco like and it had a sharp finish, but the flavours were very solid and it was very drinkable.

Best porter Ive ever had.  Perfect smokey taste.  The chocolate, coffee, and caramel flavors blend together perfectly.  Hill Farmstead  may be in the middle of nowhere VT but if you like porters its worth the drive.

50 cl bottle. Black pour with a lovely and quite large light brown head. The aroma comes off rather hoppy at first with citrus orange. Quite surprising to be honest. Beneath the rather massive hoppiness, there is chocolate, sweet liquorice and roasted notes, but I think it takes a bit too much for me to smell through the hops. Though as it warms considerably, the malt complexity finally unravels; burned caramel and toasted nuts, lush chocolate and bitter coffee, even a hint of cinnamon and chocolate cake crust. The taste is magnificent. Roasted malts play with coffee, cocoa and liquorice, and hops bring a refreshing whiff of citrus. Both malts and hops contribute to the bitterness in the end of the taste, both liquorice root-like and hoppy. Drinks way to easy for a 7,5% porter. Very balanced and easy on the palate. Easily one of the best porters Ive had, though I think it is a tad too hoppy especially below 12 degrees celsius.

Bottle... Dark black pour , thin beige head , excellent lace . Aroma of chocolate and dark roast coffee . Sweet malt flavor with notes of chocolate , liquorice and dark roasted malt . Nice citrus hop bitterness . Lingering roasted malt finish . Medium bodied and carbonation . Well balanced , very enjoyable .

On tap at the brewery. Probably the best porter I have ever had. Dark black with a light brown head. Roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, some smoke. Smooth but bitter, very dry and refreshing, moderate body and average carbonation, becomes more bitter but there is a malty sweetness that lends some balance. Great.

Thick aroma of raisin. Color is brown, but perfectly opaque. Flavor is sweet up front, carrying the fruit, but dries out quickly. Just the right balance of sweet malt and dry drinkability. Beautiful silky palate. Nice rich flavors, perfect balance. Only thing holding it back is complexity, but for the style and what is being attempted, this is hard to beat.
notes of milk chocolate, bright bitter roast, cocoa, and coffee.   relatively low carbonation.    relatively sweet for a hill farmstead brew.     good, prefer twighlight of the idols.

Pour from a bottle;deep dark brown color with a very cool mocha brown head. Aromas are of roasted smoky malt, and a bit of sweet caramel. Super smooth and rich in your mouth. Perfect balance of medium to full body. Initial sweet roasted malt flavor expands in complexity to include coffee, molasses, bitter hops, and cocoa. Nice long finish of aforementioned flavors. Best porter I have had in some time. Yum.

Brown/black pour.  2 fingers of brown head.  Coffee roasted malt and bitter chocolate.  Very slight bitterness roasted malt coffee burnt brown sugar. Dark chocolate slight bit of wood.  Medium bodied.  A joy to drink. Now i want more.

(Bottle) Pours dark brown to black with a large sized pale brown head. The aroma holds caramelly and chocolaty malt alongside grapefruity, piny and floral hops. Undertones of tar, ash, meat, ginger, blackberries, cinnamon and cardamom, sweet liquorice alongside a tiny whisper of smoke. Round and friendly nose, really well balanced. The flavour is light sweet, light to medium bitter and tiny acidic. Asphalt, chocolate, coffee, dark caramel, mild citrus, flowers and sweet liquorice. The mouthfeel is super clean and round with a medium carbonation. Pine, tar, liquorice and coffee on the finish. Medium bodied.

Farmhouse, Burlington, VT 12oz ($6.50): Pours a beautiful black with a brown head. Aroma is burnt malts, burnt malts, and smoke, and burnt malts. Normally, I would say a porter has chocolate and coffee; this one doesnt. All that there is is burnt malts and a delicious sweet fruitiness. Its like candy that went through a fire of deliciousness. That being said, this is anything but a chugger. I had to nurse this baby, but each wee sip was a pleasure. I like this beer, and am not surprised that it somehow found itself in the 100th percentile.
On draft pour.  Pitch black with a thick inch tan head. Smokey robust porter.  Smooth and very well made.  Perfectly smokey.

Draft at CCB. Loads of chocolate malt and some smoke/roast on the nose. Poured a dark black porter color with a nice dark, tan head. Solid lacing. Taste is very similar with a slick mouthfeel. Very drinkable with a nice bitter finish (but not too bitter). Great stuff.

500ml bottle.

Pours pitch black with a big rocky tan head that recedes very slowly and leaves great lacing.

Aroma is not as roasty as I was expecting with more sweet milk chocolate and malty sweetness.  There is a light roasted black malts and coffee beans.

Taste mirrors the aroma with some smooth caramel malts and dark chocolate dominating up front.  The backbone is roasty but not overly so.  There is definitely some chocolate sweetness in the finish as well as a hint of smoke.

The mouthfeel is excellent and about as creamy as Ive ever had in a porter.  Solid carbonation.

This is one of the sweeter porters Ive tasted recently and almost tastes like a smoky chocolate stout.  Really good stuff.

Hill Farmstead is quickly becoming one of my favorite breweries. 

Nice brown pour with aromas of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate.\

Taste is of dry chocolate, roast, breaf and caramel malts. A very oily mouth feel , but it is good.

pours very dark brown with a thin (growler filled from tap) but persistent dark mocha head. dark complex malts, coffee and resinous hops - black ipa feeling here. smoke, chocolate, coffee and big american hops. low carbonation, medium body and long resinous-grassy hops. as usual, impressive.

This is what a porter can be and it really blew me away.  Taste is dry roasted and chocolaty with just the right amount of clean spicy/citrusy hop profile as to not take away from the important elements of this porter.  I couldnt believe a porter could be this amazing.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured a dark reddish brown color with an average frothy light brown head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate toasted chocolate malt, coffee and alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy toasted malt sweet flavor with a medium complex dark malt bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration. Standout complex brew.
Bottle from Ephraim release. Holy mother of everything holy this beer is ridiculous!!!!!! Huge roasty flavors with balanced malt sweetness backing it. Baltic type aromas. You are a magician Shaun!

Picked up for me by afksports from the source. Poured from the bottle into a snifter. Pours a thick black with a creamy tan head. Aromas of ash, coffee, small hint of chocolate. Taste appears in the exact opposite direct, chocolate, with a coffee middle and a slightly ashen finish. Probably the best porter this side of Founders. Highly recommended.

Deep, dark pour.  Nice brown head.  Rich chocolate fudge, some good hops, roast, coffee aroma.  Flavor is full and rich.  Decadent yet still balanced.  Hops and roast just are amazing in this brew.  Thanks to the guys at my birthday tasting for this gem.

500ml bottle courtesy of dfclav. thanks, michael! pours a rich, deep, chestnut brown with a massive, rocky, mocha head that has great retention and leaves beautiful, thick, sticky rings of lace. aroma is wonderful with heavy notes of dark chocolate, burnt brownies, black espresso, and smokey, roasted malts backed by notes of toasted nuts, vanilla, and woody earth with subtle hints of grassy hops and dark fruits. flavor is absolutely amazing as well with rich, roasted malts, bitter bakers chocolate, and toasted almonds backed by smokey charcoal, toffee, and mild licorice with subtle notes of earthy hops and sweet molasses on the finish. palate is medium bodied and perfectly carbonated with a great balance of rich sweetness and bold bitterness that makes for a great drinking experience. overall, a fantastic, world class porter.

Split a 500ml bottle three ways. Poured a dark brown color (almost black) small dark tan head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee notes, roasted goodness, touch of hops. Flavor is rich roasted chocolates, coffee, roasted notes. Something about this one is just great. So great.

500ml Bottle:  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, roasting, hops, and slight caramel.  Poured black in color with a huge, foamy, creamy, dense, brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is medium sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of malt, roasting, chocolate, coffee, hops, and slight caramel.  Medium body.  Lightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Medium sweet, light to medium bitter, chocolate, malt, roast, hop, coffee finish is lightly dry.  7.5%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

(22oz bomber thanks to jyoungsbcp) jet black pour, thick creamy dark tan head, quite viscous in the glass. Nose of honey, very roasty, super rich and awesome smelling. Taste is dry and roasty, cream, sweet, nutty, complex. Dry but slightly sweet and roasty finish. Great. Tiniest bit of raisin crept in on the palate finish. An awesome porter.

One of the most outstanding of the group from Hill Farmstead. Very dark with fine foam, rich coffee and dark chocolate aromas, fine foam contributing to a lightly creamy rich, buttery feel. More chocolate as it finishes, lingering cocoas an touch of vanilla. Without particulate feel and no herbal bitterness - common flaws of this type of beer. A curious and and very intensified and rich manifestation of a typically "little brotherish" (to stout, impy stout) style. Spectacular.

Dark rich very dark brown body, initially overflowing head.  One and a half inches retained thick light rbown foamy head after several minutes.Aromas are malty, chocolate, light roast. Thick creamy mouthfeel, rich, some boozyness.  Very drinkable but a sipper.  Excellent porter.Thanks Hopdog!

500mL bottle, courtesy of joet. Thanks, Joe! Pours an oily dark chocolate color; fine-bubbled medium-tan head. Oily, nutty chocolate and lightly roasted coffee in the aroma; rich and oily; delicious. Medium-full body; relaxed carbonation. Tasty, hugely oily and nutty porter with a vibrant coffee and chocolate character; oily, dense, mouthcoating porter. Yum. Could use a touch more CO2. Lasting oily, nutty, chocolate finish. To reiterate: yum.

P: 3/5. opaque black.  a reasonable deep tan head, receding after some time, no lacing.  

A: 4/5. deep, sweet roasty caramel malty

F: 9/10. nice roasty sweetness.  some astringency, bur not really strong. wonderful smoothness for a robust porter.  

M: 2/5

O: 8/10
Pours a dark brown to black with frothy tan head, nose is milk chocolate chocolate and chicory. First sip is great with dark chocolate and roasted malt, nice dry finish for a porter. Great beer.
terrific porter. super well balanced, roasty, smokey, burnt, a lil hoppyness, full body thats very creamy and easy drinking, pleasant aftertaste. drinks very well, i want more!

This really flirts with perfection - a clean and focused strong porter. Strong chocolate and coffee. Rich and bold... big shout out to joet for orchestrating an excellent labor day, and the norbay crew for rocking out

(Draught)  Pours an opaque black body with a medium tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, vanilla, coffee, caramel, and roasted malt.  Flavor of coffee, roasted malt, green hops, tobacco, caramel, and vanilla.

Had this on tap and from bottle various times. Pours a black liquid with a tan head that holds up and leaves lacing as it falls. smell is rich is cocoa roast with mild dark malt with a light crisp grassy hop. taste is rich with cocoa and dark maltiness with a touch of roastiness. malt driven with a balancing bitterness. mouthfeel is rich and full/medium body. carbonation is low and creamy.

Boy, when Shaun says "robust" hes not kidding!  Bottle at Highland Lodge. Very dense black color, lets no light through (of course, I drank it by candlelight at sunset, on the porch).  Aroma of concentrated espresso and 70% cacao dark chocolate. Taste is rich, thick dark chocolate mousse. Would love to try the BA version.

Pours a pitch black color with a thick brown head. Excellent aroma of roasted malt, black chocolate and hops. Superb flavor of roasted malt, black chocolate and hops, the finish is bitter and slightly dry. The body is medium with a creamy texture and medium carbonation. This is amazing, its the ultimate porter!

750ml growler thanks to Glouglouburp.  I didnt share this baby with anybody.  ;-)  ours black with a brown head.  Nose is of coffee and roast malt.  Taste is of coffee and chocolate.  Mouthfeel is medium-thin, dry and mouth-coating.  This one packs a punch as I got a buzz from one pint!  A good porter.

Drank on tap (12 oz) at Three Penny Taproom in Montpelier, Vermont, on July 29, 2011. Black, small beige head. Sweet aroma of malted barley, notes chocolate, coffee and caramel. Malted chocolate taste a little sweet, well caffeinated, good bitterness of cocoa. A very good strong but sweet porter!

500mL bottle, sent from Glouglouburp (thanks Dany), split with Matts_Property, pours black with a voluminous, slowly receding light brown / tan head. Aroma is intensely roasty and hoppy with subtleties of licorice, dark chocolate and burnt espresso. Flavour is very roasty and hoppy, off-set by some chocolatey sweetness and a hint of licorice - finishes chocolatey sweet and hoppy at the same time. Full-bodied, especially for a porter. Most excellent.

500ml bottle split with mcberko. Pours solid black with a tan coloured head. Aroma of darkly roasted coffee, chocolate, caramel, a tiny bit of spice, roasted malts and hops. Flavour of dark coffee, and caramel malts, initially bitter with a spice kick. Full bodied for a porter. Roasted and bitter. Nice.

Growler.  The much anticipated pour yields a body of dark chestnut to mahogany with a small, neat, creamy edge of light mocha foam sitting at the head.  Skinny flares and trailing spots jut out from the surface, sheepishly holding on to the glass.  The aroma is all about the bold (yet smooth) roast, booming with notes of dry dark cocoa, roasted barley, and even a bit of meaty smoke.  Theres just a touch of blackened caramel sweetness, but not too much.  Despite being a formidable brew, the superior attenuation is immediately apparent.  Flavors closely match the nose, packing that same dark, dry roasted feel, with just the slightest taste of balancing cocoa-caramel sweetness on the back end.  Toasted pumpernickel bread and roasted nuts are not out of the question, and again, some welcomed smokiness is involved.  The palate manages to display plenty of substance while maintaining a relatively dry consistency, with perfectly delicate carbonation levels.  This is just an outstanding product from start to finish.  Theres very little to complain about.  In all my years, this is one of the more refined and enjoyable porters Ive come across.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2013 My beer of the year 2011. Bottle. Thick dark brown beer with a brown head. Big roasted malt nose. Lots of coffee and a hint of chocolate. Tastes like a rich hand made chocolate pudding. You can almost feel the chocolate bits in your teeth. A rich delicious beer. And it has alcohol too! Every sip tastes better and better.

On tap at the Black Back in Waterbury VT.
Pours a dark brown bordering on black with a tight tan head that sticks around for a while. Smells of roasted grains, coffee and chocolate, licorice and a hint of alcohol. Taste is smooth dark chocolate mixed with coffee and anise with hints of alcohol molasses and dark dried fruits. Velvety smooth creamy mouthfeel, moderate level of carbonation, medium to thick body. This is a fantastic porter! I just wish it were a little easier to come by.

Growler poured Sat. 7/2, sampled Thurs 7/7.  Pours completely opaque brown/black with thick tan head.  Smells and tastes very, very strongly of coffee.  Coffee all throughout.  Dark chocolate as well.  Perhaps a little thin on the mouthfeel, but Im not complaining.  Taste is just outstanding,

Bottle.  Dark brown, almost black pour, with a nice large tan head, excellent lacing.  I beautiful beer.  Smooth milk chocolate, roasted malt, light coffee, caramel, licorice, and nuts.  Nice silky mouthfeel.  An excellent robust porter.

Draft at Eulogy.

Pours a pitch black color thats completely opaque with a half finger dark mocha head that slowly settles into a thin lasting ring. Minimal spots of lacing left behind.  

Deep roasted malt aroma with a good balance of silky chocolate.  Subtle lactic cream along with hints of roasted espresso/coffee, chicory, oatmeal, nut and toffee.  Very nice roast character without smelling acrid or burnt.  Lots of coffee character without overpowering the chocolate notes

Medium bodied with a nice balance of roasted malt an sweet silky chocolate notes.  Bittersweet chocolate, coffee/espresso, oatmeal hazelnut and toffee. Pretty toasty but still smooth with milk chocolate notes.  Easy drinking and quaffable with a well masked ABV.

Poured into a pint glass.

4.5 A: Black color. First pour yielded over a hand of head, but I got a full glass on my second pour. Three fingers of super creamy/pillowy light brown head with excellent retention and tons of ungodly thick lacing. This would have easily been a perfect score if I only needed one pour to achieve this.

4.0 S: Coffee and chocolate are the main attraction here with smoke and dark crystal malts not far behind. Good amount of roastiness as well, which strikes a good balance between the sweet maltiness. This smells very nice as is, but would be amazing if all the aromas were amplified a bit.

4.5 T: This is really tasty. Again, theres lots of coffee and chocolate. A peaty twang is there along with smoke. A healthy bit of caramel sweetness gives this robust porter the robustness. Lots of sweet maltiness overall, which is again balanced nicely by the roastiness. The taste is a lot like the nose, just more powerful.

5.0 M: Heavier medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Super creamy, especially for the ABV. Cant get much better than this.

4.5 D: This is a very good beer. Its quite robust overall, but no flavor is out of place or too strong. Really great beer that didnt need to be more than 7.5% to be delicious.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-07-2011 17:32:48

On tap at the Hill Farmstead First Anniversary Party. Served in a Hill Farmstead long-stem tulip.

Pours near black with a really nice tan/mocha head and some good lacing on the way down. The nose brings forward coffee and chocolate along with some light roasted malt character. Theres a light touch of smoke in the background. The flavor is dominated by chocolate and coffee. Light smoke and sweetness with some roast there as well. Medium body with good carbonation. Nice and creamy. Alcohol is not noticeable. Really solid brew.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 06-16-2011

Dark pour with a nice dense head, great retention. Aroma and flavor are fairly complex and very inviting. Lots of dark chocolate, hints of coffee and nuts with some dark roasted malts and a touch of bittering hops. Very well balanced and gets even better as it warms. Excellent.

Draft at Farmhouse - Pours a very dark black/brown in color with a medium dark tan head.  Aroma id strong of the spicy hops, dark roasted malts, coffee and bitter chocolate.  Flavor is hoppy and bitter.  Bitterness linger on into the finish.  Not sure I would classify this as a Porter... but really good.

Tap at Capones like most of my other HF ratings. Black with ridiculous cocoa head retention, 35 minutes in a four ounce sampler and still pouting over the top of the glass. Dusty, chocolate nose, bit of pine. Flavor very soft, milky chocolate, light liquor finish, bit of licorice, creamy smooth body and profile reminiscent of de molen, but the body says otherwise.

This poured a very dark brown color with a tan head that lasted forever!! Aroma was lots of dark roasted malts but not overly roasted and burt, lots of dark chocolate too, and some citrusy hops as well. Flavor was awesome dark chocolate, roasted malts, nice balance of hop[s and even some woody notes too. Great porter.

Thanks to largadeer for sharing this.  500ml bottle.  Great appearance, darker brown in color with a large two finger tan head that lasts.  The aroma is nice and hoppy, rather piney like a black IPA but with considerable roasty/charcoal notes.  Somewhat smoky with dark chocolate notes.  The flavor is (sorry Ive only watched this show once but it applies here) LEGEN...wait for it...and it would be crazy if they used lactose in this beer because here comes the...DARY.  Damn this flavor is big, and it is good.  So much flavor and so much complexity.  Dark chocolate, roast, piney hops, and...well...awesomeness to be honest.  Medium-bodied and exceedingly dry with great hop bitterness. Wow, this beer has truly impressed me.  Best of the night.

Tap at Capones  Best porter I have had to date. The appearance was spot on. Pours black. Im not sure if the dense, dark tan head would have ever fully dissipated. It sat for 30 minutes and did not diminish at all, so who knows. Great lacing. Aroma is fresh cut wood, roast, vanilla, chocolate and some hazelnut. Taste is similar, but without the intense hazelnut. Probably the least impressive part for me, but still really good. Palate is thick and creamy, full-bodied. Really blurs the porter/stout line. Just awesome.
Bottle at Capones. Pours black. Nose/taste of heavily roasted coffee, chocolate, burnt black malts, light smoke and touch of peat. Medium body.

Tap at Capones and later at Eulogy for RBSG Philly 2011/Philly Beer Week. The pour is midnight with a utterly insane deep mocha head erupting and sitting still for about 30 minutes. No joke. Infinite retention and giant lace of Jesus. Nose is wet tobacco, chili pepper, hazelnut liquor similar to De Molen Heaven & Hell. Taste has some salty chocolate bacon, savory umami, deep and rich baker chocolate and spicy chili pepper. Buttery, full, De Molen imperial stout palate. Wickedly rich. Unfair to put this in the porter category. Definitely the new superlative for style.

Draft. Pours reddish brown with an off white head. Malty sweet aroma with light roast, vanilla, toffee, and a hint of dark fruits. The flavor has sweet malts, coffee, a hint of dark fruit, and a light roast. Nice.

Pours black with a nice tan head. Aroma is of heavy roast, coffee, and some light chocolate. Taste is complex with a nice, silky smooth mouthfeel, chocolate, roast, coffee with a slight tell of alcohol on the finish.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2012 Bottle. Black pour with a finger of tan foam and heavy lacing. Very chocolatey aroma, light roastiness, a bit of coffee. Taste is bitter dark chocolate, roasted malt finish (burnt toast). Palate is maybe this beers strongest point, very well carbonated, pillowy with a nice lingering finish. Packed with flavors, yet unagressive and velvety. The best porter Ive had.

On tap at Capones.  Ebony with some tan froth.  Nose is smoke, oak, coffee and chocolate.  Medium to full body with a tang.  Taste is smoke, walnut, chocolate, prune and earthy hops.  Coffee just peeking out in the finish.

Tasted from a bottle in mid-April 2011.  Pours oily black with a thick tan head that slowly recedes to a thin, even blanket of lace.  The nose is roasted dark malt, freshly roasted coffee, light vanilla, and dark chocolate.  The flavor is lightly sweet vanilla up front, moving to more roasted malt and coffee notes along with dark chocolate.  The body is full with light carbonation and a long roasted coffee and dark chocolate finish.

On Tap at Hill Farmstead 1st Ann. 
Pours a Dark Black/Brown with a tan head.  Aroma is Dark Chocolate, Roast, rich coffee.  Thick and creamy in the mouth, flavor is a dark swirl of chocolate, burnt wood, light twinge of smoke, coffee.  The list could go on and on, a very deep beer, Very Good.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2012 On tap at Hill Farmsteads first anniversary celebration. One of the best porters ever. Awesome balance of chocolate, cocoa nib, coffee, and roast, all in the perfect proportions. Thick rich palate with an awesome roasty finish. An example setter for the style, and what all other porters should try to emulate.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2012 On tap at Hill Farmsteads 1st Anniversary. Gorgeous black pour with a tight light brown head. Aroma and flavor both have a delightful smokiness to them that reminded me of the Fear and Trembling series. Further chocolate, roasted malt, and molasses presence really makes this a complex and balanced porter. Great stuff.

16.9 oz bottle.  Pours a deep dark cola with a huge thick and creamy light brown head.  Aroma of lightly sweetened roasted malts, chocolate, barley and caramel.  Taste of lightly sweetened roasted  and toasted malts, chocolate, barley, caramel and toffee.

Thanks turdferguson for sharing. Pours a nice dark black with two fingers of creamy tan head. Nose is really nice, sweet roasted coffee and bakers chocolate with notes of fruit skins and lightly roasted grain. Coffee roast and bitter chocolate in the flavor with mild notes of burnt grain and a touch of sweetness. Medium grain and hop bitterness on the palate, excellent representation of the style.

Bottle.  Pours a dark bruin near black body with a tan coffee head with both good retention and nice lacing.  Aromatically dark and roast y.  Chewy hop tones, burnt malt, light smoke, some roasted bitter chocolate tones.  Coco and drying bitter coffee esk finish.  Big full body with a hint of warmth easily let down by the dark roast.  Its going going gone. Hats off.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2013 bottle. pours black with creamy tan head. looks great. aroma has cocoa and big roast kick to it. flavors are very big with roasty and sweet cocoa malts. finishes with that off putting sourish dark malt quality with a strong booze note. this had promise but I dont think it finished well at all, making it rather undrinkable.

bottle sampled next to Founders Porter just to see how close these beers really are. Everett was a few months fresher. Both pours pitch black but Everett poured initially with a creamy tan head but both heads didnt last long, Founders head was fizzier. Both beers have a big dark chocolate aroma but Everett had more depth with sweet brown sugar and currant notes. Taste wise Founders porter was a bit ashier while Everett had a big dark fruit sweetness with some tobacco and molasses to it. Overall both beers are similar, I think Everett has more depth and a better mouth feel but Founders Porter is great too. Recipe wise Everett uses Roasted barley while Founders Porter uses black patent. Both stellar porters. The more recent batches have been killer.

Opened on May 4, 2011. I have previously had the barrel-aged version, which was really nice, so I was looking forward to this. Thanks to RSchaeffer for the extra!

Pours black with two full fingers of thick tan head. Shaun knows his aesthetics. Ridiculous lacing. The only complaint is that the second pour yields almost too much head (four full fingers).

Smoky roast coffee, tons of milk chocolate, dark fruit and a nice milky creaminess. Toffee sweetness alongside a really pleasant spiciness. The sweeter and milky parts remind me of Velvet Merkin, but this features much more spicy balancing complexity and "robust," smoky elements.

Both milk and [xx%] cocoa dark chocolate, espresso roast coffee beans, peppercorn, and an ashy smokiness. The spicy oak found in the -bal version is here too. How? - I have no idea. More or less maps onto the nose.

At first, this has too much carbonation - medium-bodied, with full, expanding-in-the-mouth carbonation. Thirty minutes later, the creaminess characteristic of HFS comes through, and the body feels appropriately fuller.

Different, but pleasantly so. Its almost exactly what I expected - spicy, somewhat smoky, rich, quietly oaky, with coffee and chocolate. A winner.

Bottle.  Pours dark, dark brown with a tight, small bubbled tan head.  Looks fantastic in the glass.  Nose is deep roasted malt, semi-sweet chocolate, coffee.  Flavor is really rich and complex.  Lots of roast, some sweeter malts, a bit of a natural tartness that works very well with the bitter and sweeter notes. Thanks Shaun!

Draft @ Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty coffee and chocolate aroma. Roasted malty coffee and chocolate flavor. Has a roasted malty chocolate finish with a long coffee finish.
Bottle.  Wow, what a beer...... Pours a fairly viscous brown / black.  Light smoke and cocoa dust dominate the nose.  Heavy on the palate, roasty and damn amazing!

En fût. Verre de 10 oz dégusté au Siboire (Sherbrooke, QC). Arôme: Forte odeur de chocolat et de café torréfié. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence dun mince col beige mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de café torréfié et de chocolat avec une pointe de vanille. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Torréfaction en arrière goût. (Rating #3619)

Bottle. Thanks! Pours a dark brownish black hue, near opaque, frothy brownish head laces well, stays as a decent layer. Aromas are chocolate, dry roastiness, with some cocoa, soda bread, touches of coffee, dry florals, and some grass. Toffee, toast. Initial is medium bodied, coffee and good roast, cocoa, toffee, and and floral hops. Lingering toffee, roast, and lingering smokiness. Some ash, toast, and caramel. Really nice and roasty, dry and bitter. Finish is smokey, earthy, roast with lingering sweet cocoa, toffee. Very well done, speaks to the Barrel Aged version I had previously. Very nice.
Growler, thanks j12601. Dark pour with tan head. Roasted, chocolate aroma. Flavors include chocolate, roasted and toasted malts,a touch of light caramel sweetness.

Verre de 10 oz, au Siboire. Arômes très maltés, présentant une forte présence de chocolat noir et une touche houblonnée et résineuse. Robe noire et opaque, effervescence moyenne et légère dentelle moka. Extrêmement complexe en bouche, les saveurs maltées (fruits mûrs, caramel brûlé, chocolat noir, touche boisée) sont très bien exprimées, sans que la bière ne soit sucrée. Très longue finale amère de chocolat noir et de houblon résineux. Vraiment incroyable !

Tap @ RnH.  Nice aroma of chocolate, vanilla, alcohol, roastyness.  The appeareance is deep brown, tan head.  The flavor is chocolate, vanilla, roast, coffee, cream.  Medium to medium/thick in body.  The finish is smooth coffee, pine hops, very nice.  Very good.  Almost crosses the line from porter to stout.

Draft at rnh in NYC with pat, Andrew and the Brewer. What a great Porter, Jesus!  Pours dark brownish black body with small white lacing. Aroma is vanilla, molasses,  delicious roast. Mouthfeel is perfect with notes noted in the aroma. Great
Draft at rnh.. Deep black color. Lots of flavor smells of fruit and malt. Almost like a stout. Reallt good
Draft pour @ rattle. Pour really dark brown.  Strong lacing of off white/tan.   Lactic, and dark chocolate,  bitter and smokey.

5  oz flight draft. Pours a maroon blackish-brown with a spotty, somewhat lacy, white head. Aroma of fresh dark wheat, vanilla, soft, mild coffee beans, with roasty, woody, earthy notes that border on sweet mustiness. Slight hints of anise and pepper. Full smoky, malty, satin richness with dark candied sugar and molassess notes in the modestly bitter finish. Excellent porter. Best Ive ever had.

Growler poured into my Hill Farmstead glass... Pours a dark brown, almost black with a nice medium tan head. Good carbonation, retention is nice, no lacing... Aroma is outstanding, the epitome of what a porter should smell like, perfect coffee, a hint of alcohol, and dark fruits, simply perfect... The taste is equally perfect. Only thing that I wish it had was smoke to come to close to the Captain Lawrence Imperial Smoked porter. Roasted coffee with hints of chocolate, a slightly bitter finish. Did I say perfect?

Oil in a glass. Big tan head that pretty much paints the side of the glass. Aromas of chocolate, vanilla, and what seems like cedar. A definite woodiness to it. Slight bit of alcohol wafting up as well. Chocolate taste mingled with an alcohol bite. Warming and delicious. Vanilla taste as well, mixed with a nice bitterness. Great beer.

In short: A uber-hoppy porter with a complex malt bill.  Great brew.
How: Tap at Hill Farmstead Winter Gathering 2011
The look: Black body topped by a persistent small tan head
In long: Hoppy and roasted nose with green resinous hops over a burnt chocolate cake, almost black-ipa-ish aroma.  Taste has a nice malt complexity, medium roasted, creamy chocolate cake, caramel, raisins, molasses.  Then comes a truckload of leafy resinous hops.  Full and lively body.  I could drink gallons of this.  Holy crap this was good.  Ive heard it is based on the Ølfabrikken Porter (brewery with whom Hill Farmstead brewer worked) except that Everett is cranked-up the American way.  The first time I visited that brewery I was blown away.  Hill Farmstead is truly the absolute best new American brewery, and certainly one of the top best brewery on the planet.  Im positive about that.  The only thing that could make me more positive would be a smoking hot horny hot chick with HIV.

Growler from the brewery. Very Interesting nose with strong nutty/toasty notes. Mouthfeel is good - soft carbonatation - with a hint of smoke. Could be a little more hops in there but still a very good robust porter.

Tap at Blind Tiger. Pours a deep brown. Nice earthy and smoky qualities in the aroma; notes of wet coffee grounds and licorice. Flavor has plenty of coffee and a slight meaty quality. Some slight hop sting to go with rich chocolate malt. Roasty goodness.

tap @ Blind Tiger - nice roasted chocolate malts, earthy smokiness, hint of anise, bitter hops, with some floral citrus notes. Dark fruits, touch of prunes and raisins. Dry finish with a hoppy kick. Very nice.
Very rich molasses and dark roasted coffee nose. Taste is moderately sweet, moderately bitter, lots of chocolate, lots of espresso, light caramel, and a citrus hop finish. Damn I love this brewery.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2011 Draught from B-tiger. Poured a dark with mild white smallish head, aroma choc coffee and malts, very good. 

Re rate  from Brouwerij Lane in Dec 2011 - inky black consistency, actuall way better this time.

A: The pour is a very dark brown with some definite red notes when held to the light. A thin layer of tan foam.

S: Theres a slight smoke to the aroma as well as some peat. Roasted malts, dark and bitter chocolate, and quite a bit coffee. There are some sort of surprising dark fruits, but a lot of licorice.

T: A lot of coffee and roasted malt flavor with some bitter dark chocolate. Its sort of bitter and astringent, however, with some definite ash and char. Theres a good bit of smoke notes to it. Also, a lot of oak/wood flavor to this, which was sort of surprising.

M: Medium in body with a smooth and full carbonation.

D: A bit too ashy to be super drinkable, but still a solid beer. Glad to have tried this.
UPDATED: DEC 16, 2011 Nose is alcohol, port, rotten fruit, sweet tobacco, feel is mediumthin, carb is quite low, taste is port, alcohol, hazel, weak mint, then bitter hops

On tap. Pours an opaque deep black with a creamy light brown head. A pleasant rostiness in the nose, fairly chocolatey. Medium body, very soft almost creamy mouthfeel, sweet hard roasted malts, vanilla and licorice. Discreet bitterness. Extremely smooth and drinkable. 190211

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2011 On tap at Hill Farmstead Winter Gathering 2010..
Appearance : Black with a small head. Light lacing.

Aroma : Nice roasted malt with light coffee and light hops. Nice chocolate.

Taste : Nice hops with light wood. Nice chocolate. Finish roasted malt, chocolate and hops. Light long bitterness. Hops are a bit floral and taste fresh. Nice soft carbonation, great palate. Light spices also.

Overall : Wow this is good. Really well balanced and really complex. Not too strong. Rather drinkable. Awesome soft carbonation. Nice sweetness mixed with coffee and chocolate flavours. Very deep. Nice surprise there. I cant wait to try the Oak Aged version. 110218 9,3,9,4,17;4.2 Update 110603 from 500ml bottle. Amazing beer. Perfect fluffy but soft carbonation. Lots of lacing and very long foam retention. Perfectly balanced with great coffee, hops, chocolate and light smoked malt all along. Insanely drinkable. Appearance 3 to 5. Palate 4 to 5. Over 17 to 16. Score 4.2 to 4.4

From tap at MikkellerBar. Pours pitch black with a creamy, dense and chocolate brown head. Aroma is dark chocolate, roasted malt and vague tarish. Lingering dark roasted malty, liqourice, dark chocolate and distinct bitter hoppy. Thick liqourice, chocolate and citrusy hoppy flavoured. Mixed sweet liqourice and bitter hoppy finish. Lasting dark roasted malty impression.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2012 My Bottom Line:
Raisins, molasses and dark chocolate thrive in this sumptuous Robust Porter, effortlessly moving into a levelled bitterness of resinous hops and roasted malts. I cannot imagine a better Robust Porter.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam covers the brown-edged black, lacing nicely.
-The mouthfeel is chewy, crunchy and nourishing, yet lets itself be drunk easily.
-Caramel sweetness and resinous hop bitterness are well balanced in the finish.
-The malt flavors are truly tantalizing. This is as complex as it is satisfying for dark beer lovers. They also linger languorously in the finish. Wow.

Many bottles (weeee!!) and on tap at Hill Farmstead and at the Siboire.
Black colour with a light brown head, nice look. Aroma: Vinious, roasted maltiness, dark fruit. Good filling mouthfeel. Flavour: pleasant roasted maltiness, chocolate, dark fruit, coffee.

Flavour is caramel, liquorice, roasted malt and coffee with a hint of bitter hops. Nice balanced.

Re-rate. Black body with a medium offwhite head. Coffee, hops, roasted malt, dark chocolate, nutty. Medium carbonation. Bitter coffee end. Delicious.

Fad: Kulsort olieret øl med et fint og flot forholdsvist hvidt skumhoved. Duften er chokoladeagtig og meget porter. Smagen er igen sødlig maltet der igen tyder på porter. Igen en fantastisk øl der er overraksende.

Handbottled. Dark brown almost black colour. Light brown dense head. aroma of smoke, caramel, roast, light sweetness. flavour of asstray, smoke, caramel, flowers and herbs. Light spice. medium to full bodied. dry roasty and light sweet bitterness in the end. Heavy smoky notes. Nice.

Entered to celebrate my rating number 19,600. Draft. A black beer with a lazing dark brown head. The aroma has strong notes of chocolate combined with medium notes of roasted malt and straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of roasted malt, grain, chocolate, and straw as well as lighter notes of coffee, hops, and flowers, leading to a dry roasted finish. Nice body.

clear brown, small brown head.
aroma of roasted malts,  licorice, 
flavor is very nicely roasted grains, chocolate, good bitter hop balance, great palate, taste is really very good.

Handbottled by joergen. Thanks! Pitch black with a creamy tan head. The aroma is coffee, chocolate, fruity hops and roasted malt. The flavour is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, toasted caramel and tobacco. Long roasted finish. Great.
Draught at MikkellerBAR. Pitch black - brown head. Roasted. Nice smokey. Berries. Fruity. Medium hoppy. Smooth body. Licorice. Chocolate. Light coffee. Ashes. Fullbodied. Nice mouth full.

Poured from a growler on multiple occasions. Deep, rich brown/black in color with tan head that laces nicely. Finish is slightly malty and roasty. My favorite of all the HFB offerings. Its balance of subtle coffee, chocolate and roastiness makes for an amazing experience.

Growler filled at Hill that I took to Max and Jesss housewarming.  Pours a deep black with a thick beige head.  Big roast, lots of toast.  Smooth, tons of roast.  No alcohol notes, not huge but still well hidden.  Chocolate, roast, toast on the finish.  Very smooth.  Another great beer by Shaun.

Thanks Eric for sharing this one. Poured a dark black color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of smoke, tobacco, roast, coffee grounds, and chocolate. Tastes of chocolate, roast, tobacco, caramel, and lighter coffee.

Growler, thanks peregrinari.  Black body with brown edges, atop medium tan head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, coffee, grapefruit/orange, some roast.  Taste is moderately sweet, bittersweet chocolate, orange/grapefruit, coffee.  Medium body, some stickiness.  Nice rich flavors -- when cold, they dont seem to work very well together, but they do quite nicely when the beer gets closer to room temperature.

Pours pitch black with a light brown head.  Aroma has a touch of acetone with some coffee and hops.  Flavor is strong coffee strong hops and some citrus.  Finish is solid and only moldy sticky.  Excellent beer.

Tap at Backwoods Brewdown 10 at the Hill Farmstead.  Pours almost black/brown with a medium creamy tan head that laced the glass.  Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, vanilla, chocolate and tobacco.  Flavor of roasted malt, coffee, cocoa, hints of vanilla, smoke, caramel and nuts.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2013 Growler. Pours dark brown with a thick, tan head. Lots of char, smoke and tobacco in the aroma. Flavor is high on roasted malts, with some nice, sweet malt notes. Medium in body with average carbonation and some roasty dryness and an overall smooth texture. Finishes sweet with plenty of chocolate and roasted tobacco. This is an excellent Porter. (4.2)Bottle shared at the Craft Beer Co. First Birthday Party, London. Superb porter. Rich, with fully realised roasted malt and chocolate character. Well carbonated. Great. (4.1)

[BBD 10] Opaque black color with a medium sized, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of sharp roasted malts, some vanilla bean, wood, cocoa, and a touch of smoke.  Taste of cocoa, roasted malts, sweeter caramel, burnt wood, and light alcohol.

Growler shared at the 4th release of CDC. I heard lots of great things about Hill Farmstead IPAs so I was rather duprised that when I started pouring this elixir from the Growler to be greeted by a pitch black medium bodied liquid sitting beneath an average sized foamy beige head. Aroma is very toasty with notes of coffee, chocolate,earth and grassy hops. Medium bodied with good carbonation, especially from an open growler, and a lingering burnt aftertaste. Flavors of coffee beans, burnt toast and charred malts. This is one dark rosary well done beer.
